To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company challenged brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to a unique race. The race would pit man against car and brother against brother in the Yorkshire Dales of northern England. Jonny would drive a car on the roads, while his younger brother Ali would ride a mountain bike across the countryside. "I’m looking forward to it," Jonny said at the start line. "I’ve never done anything like this before: it’s exciting! These roads have beautiful views, and it’s very cold, so I’ll stay warm in the car." Alistair was also eager, wearing full winter cycling gear, unlike Jonny in jeans and a sweatshirt. "To be honest," Alistair said, "I’ve seen his driving before, so I’m not sure he’ll make it. I might just stop for a cup of tea halfway up."

The race began at Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and would end at Fleet Moss, Yorkshire’s highest road, 350 meters up. The car might have an advantage, but Alistair faced a tough start with a steep 25 percent incline. After a quick handshake, they were off. Alistair sprinted on his bike up the hill and across the country to Fleet Moss, while Jonny got into the car and hit the road. The next time they would see each other was at the finish line. The question was, who would get there first?

Jonny’s confidence was quickly tested. Just 15 seconds into the drive, a giant tractor blocked the road. "Welcome to Yorkshire," he joked to the cameraman in his car. "If Alistair beats me, it’s because of this farmer!" After passing the tractor, Jonny continued into the mist. Meanwhile, Alistair struggled with the slope. A few miles in, he had to carry his bike up the hill, past walls and over fences. Sheep watched as the Olympic champion kept a steady pace, carrying his bike. Finally, he reached the summit. With open ground ahead and the sun shining, Alistair picked up speed.

In the car, Jonny faced another challenge. The narrow village roads were not built for speed. He slowed to a crawl to navigate a tight corner and a stream on the road. Once clear of the village, he raced to the finish line. Neither brother knew how close the other was. As Jonny sped to Fleet Moss, Alistair was flying across his last field and back onto the road, approaching the finish from the other side. Head down, legs pumping, he reached the line and braked. Alistair looked up and asked the crowd, "Is he here?" When they said no, he celebrated. Minutes later, Jonny arrived. "Well done," Jonny said, disappointed. "I’m gutted."

Text: 'The silence is what you notice when you play on Centre Court at Wimbledon. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass; you toss it up to serve; you hit it and hear the echo of your shot. The trimmed grass, the history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds all create a feeling of being enclosed from the outside world. The quiet helps my game. In a tennis match, I try hard to focus only on the contest and the point I’m playing. The silence is broken by noise when a point ends: applause, cheers, people shouting your name. I hear them, but as if from far away. I don’t notice the fifteen thousand people watching every move my opponent and I make. I am so focused that I forget there are millions watching me around the world as I play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the biggest match of my life. I always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, my lifelong coach, taught me early on that this was the biggest tournament. By age 14, I was telling my friends I’d play there one day and win. Before 2008, I played and lost twice, both times against Federer – in the final the year before, and the year before that. The 2006 defeat wasn’t so hard. I was just happy to have made it that far at twenty. Federer beat me easily, more easily than if I’d believed in myself more. But losing in 2007 left me devastated. I knew I could have done better; it wasn’t my ability that failed, but my mindset. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room. Losing always hurts, but it hurts more when you have a chance and waste it. Toni, a tough coach, usually doesn’t comfort me; he criticizes me even when I win. But seeing how upset I was, he told me not to cry, that there would be more Wimbledons and finals. I told him he didn’t understand, that this might have been my last chance. I know how short a professional athlete’s career is, and I want to make the most of it. Every moment counts, but some moments count more, and I let a big one pass in 2007. Toni couldn’t ease my grief, but he was right. Another chance came in 2008, just a year later. I was confident I’d learned from that defeat; this time, my mindset wouldn’t fail me. The best sign was my belief that I would win. At dinner with family and friends the night before the final, we didn’t talk about the match. I didn’t forbid it, but they knew I was already playing the match in my mind. Until the start of play, that space was mine alone.'

A young, idealistic Englishwoman named Jane Goodall arrived in Africa in April 1957. In one of her first letters home, she wrote, "I am living in the Africa I have always longed for, always felt stirring in my blood." Jane spent most of her life in Africa and became known as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. In 1963, Britain's National Geographical Society helped make her famous by producing articles and TV documentaries about her research on chimpanzees. Her fame grew with her own writing, including award-winning children's books and the 1971 bestseller "In the Shadow of Man," translated into 47 languages.

Jane Goodall is one of the most celebrated female scientists of the 20th century, possibly second only to Marie Curie. However, her fame sometimes overshadows her real achievements. Many articles and books about her life focus on her adventurous spirit, her dreams of living with wild animals, and her role as a feminist, but these stories can undervalue her work. Based on the number of academic references to her research, the success of her students, and the data from her 40-year study, Jane Goodall should be seen as a pioneering zoologist. Her main achievement is that she helped us understand the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees.

Before Goodall's work, people misunderstood the dangers of wild chimpanzees. No one knew they ate meat or used tools. We didn't realize they shared emotions with humans or had social systems like ours. We also didn't know that chimpanzee communities across Africa had different cultural traditions. Her book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe" (1986), is a key work in chimpanzee research. Her long-term study in Gombe, Nigeria, is considered one of the great scientific achievements by biologist Stephen Jay Gould. Jane Goodall changed how we study animals and how we think about ourselves, as chimpanzees are our closest relatives.

Even as a child, Jane showed signs of her future career. At five years old, in 1939, she disappeared one afternoon. The police and neighbors searched for her. When she reappeared, she explained that she had hidden in a henhouse for five hours to see how hens lay eggs. This curiosity foreshadowed her future as a biologist.

Shirley Ford is a voiceover artist known for her work in children's TV, cartoons, and educational programs. During our conversation, she demonstrated her ability to switch between different voices, including a cheeky 8-year-old boy, a tired mother, an amusing elderly Scottish woman, and a fast-talking alien. Shirley explains that doing voiceovers is more than just creating funny voices; it's about bringing scripts to life for an audience that can't see you. Many famous actors want to do voiceover work, but they often don't get roles because they're used to acting with their whole bodies.

Shirley started her career with a drama course, intending to become a traditional actor. However, she got her break in voiceover work when she was asked to audition for a rabbit in a cartoon. She found success in this field and realized it was the right path for her. Shirley often voices small boys and girls because her voice is lighter than male actors, and hiring child performers involves complex procedures that production companies prefer to avoid.

Her work ranges from cartoons to educational videos and adverts. She finds cartoons particularly enjoyable because of the interaction with other actors. Shirley emphasizes the importance of a good showreel to showcase an artist's abilities, as competition is tough. She attributes her success to persistence and setting goals, recommending specialist workshops for those interested in voiceover careers. Shirley is passionate about voices and often finds herself speaking in different accents even after leaving the studio. Her children are used to hearing her talk in various voices.

People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This makes sense because cartooning is a dream job for many kids, like being a race car driver. However, most people eventually choose more practical careers, like becoming a tax lawyer or working in auto parts. The idea of making a living by drawing doodles, like those in school notebooks, seems unrealistic. Yet, some people do become cartoonists. Most cartoonists have wanted to do it for a long time. In my case, I loved comic strips as a child, contributed to school publications, and was known as 'the kid who draws.' I studied graphic design in college and showed my illustrations to different companies after graduating. I was fortunate to find a newspaper looking for political cartoons on local issues. I created some ideas, they bought them, and soon I was earning enough to support myself.

To become a cartoonist, you don't need a university degree, much money, or even great drawing skills. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as teachers. The technical barriers are low, but it's still a challenging job. You shouldn't try to become a cartoonist unless you feel you can't do anything else. It's easier to get a regular job that pays the bills and leaves time for family and hobbies. The more skills you have, the better your chances of making a living with your art. I've done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I've also been a writer, caricaturist, and sometimes a designer. I don't turn down work because you can learn a lot from jobs you don't really want to do. It helps to be intelligent, well-read, and curious about the world.

What about the business side of cartooning? There was a time when many cartoonists had regular jobs with newspapers and magazines, but those days are ending. Today, cartooning is mostly an entrepreneurial activity. You have to create and sell your work. Cartoonists with average talent but good business skills often do better than artistic geniuses. It's surprising how many people are afraid someone will steal their ideas, even if they've never sold a cartoon. Some are so worried they won't show their work to anyone. To protect your work, just draw a 'c' for 'copyright,' circle it, and write your name and the date. But realistically, it's more likely no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it goes viral online, it might actually be a lucky break!

Twenty years ago, I was moving house and decided to clear out some things. I chose to throw away an electric guitar my dad gave me for my 16th birthday. It was a sleek, black, Japanese-made guitar. Normally, I hate getting rid of things, so why did I want to throw this away? I took it to the rubbish dump and was about to discard it when a young man approached me, looking confused. "You’re not just going to throw that away, are you?" he asked. I said I was, already feeling a bit of regret. He asked if he could have it, and I agreed. We went our separate ways, but I felt a constant regret afterward.

A few months ago, I received an email that changed everything. It reminded me of a story about a man who lost his wedding ring in the ocean and found it years later in a fish. The email was from a guitar dealer named Keith Rushton. He wrote, "I’ve got your electric guitar." The guitar had been bought and sold several times since I gave it away. Keith found a name-and-address label on it and used my name to find me online. He contacted me through the newspaper I work for and offered to sell it back to me. I was overwhelmed with emotion. Keith's price was fair, and I was grateful. I had forgotten my dad's habit of putting name-and-address stickers on everything, including my guitar. My dad would have found this story amusing.

My parents wanted me to learn classical guitar in the 1970s when it was popular. I loved its calming sound, but I struggled to make progress. So, I switched to the electric guitar, playing simple music. It was also the era of punk music, where you didn’t need to be a great musician to be a rock star. When I received my guitar back from Keith, I remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. Holding it again, it felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I instinctively stood up and put a strap over my shoulder, as the electric guitar is meant to be played standing. My fingers remembered the chords, even though I couldn’t draw them. My fingertips felt the familiar pain of pressing the strings.

The electric guitar isn’t really a solo instrument, so now that I’m learning it again, I might need to form a band. My son is learning the saxophone, so maybe we can play together. Or perhaps there are others my age with similar experiences. We could call ourselves "The Regainers"!

There has been a lot of discussion about sleep recently. When I wrote the book "Insomniac," about people who struggle with sleeplessness, I felt like I was the only one warning about the dangers of not getting enough sleep and how it affects our minds, bodies, and moods. Insomniacs, whom I interviewed in large numbers, will tell you that sleep is crucial for our mental, physical, and social well-being. Those who struggle the most with sleep often understand its importance the best. It's good that sleep is finally getting the attention it deserves. But what about dreams? They haven't been discussed much. We often lose dreams when we wake up early, cutting off the last hour or two of sleep, which is mostly REM or 'Rapid Eye Movement' sleep, the stage rich in dreams. Our most vivid and emotionally powerful dreams happen during REM, just before we wake up. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep in REM, so someone who lives 90 years will spend six or seven years in REM. When researchers stop people from having REM sleep, they experience more intense REM the next night to make up for it. This suggests dreams have a purpose. When REM was discovered in 1953, many agreed with psychologist Sigmund Freud, who believed that understanding dreams was key to understanding the mind. However, later research did not support this idea, and the study of dreams shifted to their physical origins. Currently, there is little agreement among dream researchers, says Harvard sleep scientist Robert Stickgold. Dreams are important. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School shared a study showing that actors, writers, and directors remember and use dreams better than others. He concluded that dream use increases with interest in creativity. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection to their dreams, as films are very dream-like. But I wondered, are only artistic people using their dreams? Don’t all people, like teachers, software designers, and politicians, need to think creatively? Stickgold says dreams help us combine things in new, surprising ways, using knowledge from the past and present to find new connections. Dreams might help us see new patterns and create combinations that break our usual thinking habits. For example, Stickgold found that when people are woken from REM and asked to respond to a word, their answers are more original than when woken from other sleep stages. They ignore the obvious and make unexpected connections, which is what creativity is, according to Stickgold. I write better after intense dreams. Even a troubling dream, or one barely remembered, seems to fuel my thoughts. On those days, words and images flow so quickly that my fingers can hardly keep up. I don’t know how it works, but it does. Creativity isn’t just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world, and we all need our brains to work well. We need to think creatively and flexibly in our relationships with colleagues, family, and friends. This is why we need to dream.

Susie Ray moved from London to a small coastal town in south-west England twenty years ago. In her studio, which has a stunning sea view, you see empty frames on the walls alongside photos of her two daughters. Susie is a leading figure in the copyist art movement, known for her ability to recreate the richness of early-20th century impressionist works and the brilliance of 16th-century Caravaggio portraits. Despite her talent, she doesn't keep any of her own work. "As soon as I finish them, they go," she says. Susie is in high demand. Over her 30-year career as a copyist artist, she has recreated works by famous artists like Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her reproductions are so accurate that even art experts can mistake them for the originals. While the originals could sell for millions, her copies sell for between a few hundred pounds and £12,000, depending on the time she spends on them. Susie keeps her clients' identities mostly private, but they include galleries and private collectors. Some collectors are true art lovers, while others are motivated by status. One celebrity claims to own a Van Gogh, but it's actually a "Susie Ray Van Gogh." "Many famous people pass off my copies as originals," she says. "That's up to them." Some collectors use her copies to save on insurance by keeping the original in a bank safe. Susie is transparent about her work. She makes her reproductions look as authentic as possible, believing that doing a poor job would disrespect the original artist. She signs her name on the back of the canvas. Passing off a copy as an original is illegal, and although she knows people who have profited from it, she has never been tempted. Those who make fakes often face consequences. Susie mentions that she isn't wealthy and has faced struggles, but her situation is more stable now, and risking her reputation isn't worth it. Susie wasn't always a copyist. After earning her art degree, she worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden, earning very little. It was a good foundation for her current work and sparked her interest in plants, though it was hard to live on. She had to be very precise and get things right the first time. She has no regrets but is glad to have found something more financially rewarding. When young artists ask for advice, Susie emphasizes the importance of learning to draw accurately. She also highlights the extensive study required to do her work. Her skills allow her to do anything from drawing plants to copying 15th-century masterpieces to reproducing 20th-century abstract art. She now focuses on French impressionists, with Manet, Cezanne, and Degas as her favorites. Susie notes that people often think modern art is simple, almost like children's work. Impressionists painted quickly and freely, but they were also meticulous, making their style challenging to replicate. Despite her skills, Susie doesn't create her own original art. Isn't art about self-expression? Could a Susie Ray original be worth more than a copy? She says her work is the result of years of training and dedication, and it provides a good living. She has tried creating her own art, like oil paintings of fishing nets, but they ended up looking like photographs—good, but not exceptional. Susie is a perfectionist.

During her racing career, nothing was more important to Ellen MacArthur than the sea, except perhaps being the fastest on it. From childhood, she was obsessed with sailing. She had a unique connection with the boats that took her around the world; they worked as one. When she returned to land, everyday life seemed unimportant, and she quickly longed to be back at sea, challenging herself against nature, even in dangerous places. After finishing second in the Vendée Globe, a solo, non-stop round-the-world race, she showed me her boat, Kingfisher. It was her home and workplace for 94 days. She explained the detailed planning involved, like calculating the exact number of kitchen paper rolls needed. Preparation was crucial, she said. She proudly displayed her stock of freeze-dried food, a small gas stove, and neatly organized medical supplies. The boat was her world, and she cared for it because her life depended on it.

Now, Ellen sees the world like a boat: small, beautiful, and fragile, with limited resources. Her perspective changed during a trip to South Georgia, a remote island in the South Atlantic, where she helped with a bird survey. Seeing abandoned whaling stations made her think about how humans take what they want and move on. When I visited her office, she had just finished a heated conference call. She explained why urgent action is needed to save the planet. "No one is making more coal, oil, or gas. They are precious resources we have only once. We need to find ways not to use them up," she said. Initially, her message was to use less, but she realized there was another way to see things. Now, she focuses on re-using, passionately discussing ideas like reusable industrial carpet tiles.

For the past three years, Ellen has visited factories, mines, and power stations, speaking to governments and businesses about our dependence on non-renewable resources. "I will never be an expert," she says, "but I love learning. The current situation became something I couldn't ignore. Sailing seemed selfish in comparison. This is about finding how my voice can be most useful. It really matters." She also started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that works with businesses and education to inspire young people to rethink and redesign a sustainable future. "I do miss the adventure of being at sea," she says. "It defines me. At sea, you are connected to everything around you, focused on records, practicalities, and survival. My new message isn't as simple as saying, 'I’m going to be the fastest person around the world.' I may have been the fastest, but this is more important than anything I've done."

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and aims to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he succeeds, he could become one of the most famous teenagers of his time. With many young people spending more time on computers and video games, he hopes to inspire them to climb their own mountains or at least spend more time outdoors. Jordan's climbing team includes his father, Paul, and mother, Karen. They call themselves 'Team Romero,' and climbing Everest is just part of their goal. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to complete the Seven Summits, the highest peaks on each continent. Few achieve this before turning thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of them and might complete the challenge before he turns 20.

I spoke to several experienced Everest climbers, and none thought it was a good idea for a 13-year-old to climb the world's highest mountain. They agreed a young climber might have the physical strength but doubted if a teenager would be emotionally ready. They also questioned if a young person could have enough experience to make safe decisions during such a climb. The Romeros are aware of these opinions. Paul says, 'I know there's criticism, but I can't focus on it – there's still so much to do. Karen and I consider the risks all the time, but we trust our experience as climbers. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He's becoming strong and mature.'

I also wonder about Jordan's motivation. Is this just an ambitious father pushing his love of adventure too far? Paul insists, 'This isn't about me trying to become famous through my son's achievements. At first, Jordan talked about doing it later in life, but we thought: 'Why not now?' We regularly check with him to ensure he still wants to do it.' When I ask Jordan what he enjoys about the challenge, he says, 'I just focus on achieving my goal.'

In the past, few cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain or sail an ocean. Today, every adventure is shared online, and every climb becomes a record-setting challenge. The more daring the record, the more interest it attracts. This creates a dilemma for Jordan. While we might say that achievement often overshadows enjoyment, if Jordan wants to inspire others, he must engage with the media. This means blogging, photo shoots, and interviews. He needs to offer something spectacular, like climbing Everest. 'And you know what?' Paul says. 'If Jordan decides tomorrow that he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we'll end this project and head to the gym.'

Text: 'When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it's likely they're not listening to classical music. Most people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they probably won't know who he is. I'm studying music at university, but my classmates don't know much more about classical music than others our age. If you don't know the composers, you probably don't own their music. The statistics are discouraging for classical music fans. Only 3% of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music, and the average classical album sells just 300 copies. I find that surprising. So, why has interest in this centuries-old music declined? Older people blame TV and video games, but I don't think that's the reason. The truth is, classical music doesn't attract most people, especially teenagers, who buy the most music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who attend classical concerts, but they're a minority. Although I play in an orchestra, I'm not a big classical music fan. I enjoy many styles, but my classical music collection is probably close to that 3% figure. Why don't teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm, with many mood changes, are challenging for us. We like to talk, play, and think fast. Experts say we struggle to focus for more than three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but perfect for a pop song. Pop is simple and easy to listen to, while classical music needs time and focus. Pop music topics are more appealing than long classical pieces without lyrics. Classical music is powerful but doesn't address teenage concerns. How we listen to music has changed. In the past, families made music together at home, and playing an instrument was valued. Concerts were the only other way to hear music. Now, you can find any music online, but our lives rarely feature classical music. When did you last hear classical music in a shop? One of my teachers says classical concert audiences have grown recently. Maybe, but I doubt many are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play in various places, but I mostly see older people in the audience. I don't know why people prefer classical concerts in middle age, but if your parents love something, you might avoid it. Some blame schools for teenagers' lack of interest in classical music, but many kids are eager to play in school orchestras. They practice early and stay late to rehearse. They enjoy performing classical music, but it's not their first choice for listening. The two activities are separate. When we relax, it's always pop music.'

Bonnie Wyndham stepped out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. "I’ll make you regret I’m here," she said to the school with a smile. Her mother, who was getting out of the car from the other side, didn’t hear her, but Bonnie wouldn’t have minded if she had. Her mother already knew how she felt. Mrs. Wyndham glanced around. Almonside was an unusual school, with buildings scattered among trees on a wooded hillside; it seemed confusing at first. Then she noticed the signs on a post: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… "Riding centre," Bonnie said, suddenly interested. "Headmaster’s study," her mother replied. "This way." Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path that curved through the trees. "I wish you’d walk beside me instead of trailing behind like a dog," Mrs. Wyndham said tiredly, but she didn’t seem to expect Bonnie to change. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his office, while Bonnie waited outside. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. "Why should I just sit here?" she thought. "I’ll be expelled soon enough," she thought to herself, "so why not get it over with?" She left the building and headed towards the riding centre, following the sign. There was a charming old building for the horses and a large indoor riding area. Bonnie looked around, but no one was there. She approached the horses with respect. Bonnie always treated horses well. The horses were well cared for, she could see that immediately. Almost every stall was occupied, and she walked along, examining each horse. "I know what they’re doing here," she told a small pony, running her finger along its nose. The next horse caught her attention. "Aren’t you the best of the lot!" she exclaimed. He was brown with a bit of white. Probably lively, but Bonnie liked that. "I feel like we’ve met before," Bonnie said, stroking his neck. "In my dreams, I was riding you to victory in a big competition…" His name was Maverick. Suddenly, she couldn’t resist the urge to ride him. "I wonder where I can find a bridle and saddle for you. They must be nearby." The room with the riding equipment was – to Bonnie’s delight – unlocked. Focused on the enjoyable task of saddling Maverick, she forgot all about her mother and the headmaster. When she sat high on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen, ruler of all she surveyed. Her nickname at her previous school had been Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered it. "You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick," she said admiringly, "and I’m not joking, because I know about horses, even if I don’t know much else." She urged him into a walk, then a trot. "If I stay here, I think you and I could be great friends," she confided. She rode around the paddock. The rhythm was thrilling, a breeze brushing her cheek and making it glow. She could tell Maverick trusted her, and she felt sure he’d jump well.

I've met Cody Simpson before and have always been impressed by his quiet confidence. The 15-year-old Australian has already released several successful songs. So how did a laid-back surfer end up on stage in front of thousands of fans? "I first picked up a guitar when I was six years old and started writing songs when I was seven," Cody says, recalling how it all began. "But I was swimming every day and surfing. Those were the things that meant more to me back then; I had my life set up and so much to occupy my time. I was 13, going to high school, and then I posted a few videos online." These videos changed everything. He started with a video of a friend and himself singing at a school concert. Fans sent online comments saying they wanted more of his videos on their social networking sites. So Cody, who had recorded more at home, was happy to share them. The responses were overwhelming. Cody was a very talented swimmer. He was training hard with some of the best coaches and focusing on perfecting his sport. But then record labels came calling, and he had a tough choice to make: stay in Australia and continue swimming, or take a huge risk by signing a deal and moving with his family to the US. Cody decided to take the plunge. "It was very difficult for me – especially at such a young age – to have to choose a career for myself. Can you imagine, at 12 or 13 years old, trying to figure out what you want to do for the rest of your life?" He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the States. "It came as a big surprise to most people. I'm kind of the quiet kid," he says, remembering their shocked expressions. "I'm very modest, and I think it's important to be that way in this crazy world." So Cody packed his bags and went with his family halfway around the world, giving up one dream in the hope of making another come true. Although his family stays out of the spotlight and isn't directly involved in his career, they are there in the background. Cody says it's important to keep a tight circle of great people around you to make sure you stay grounded. Of course, we all have days of doubt. "Sometimes when I'm left alone for a while, I sit and think, 'How did my decision affect my little brother and sister?' My little brother's eight years old, and he's traveling the world, doing school on the road; he doesn't have a regular life," Cody admits. "I worry about the effect of that on him sometimes, but my family's always reassuring me that they're here to support me and encourage me in everything that I do." Success, in whatever career you choose, comes from a willingness to say "yes" to your big break, even when it's a little scary to do so. "It all just happened so fast and unexpectedly," Cody says. "Now, to be going to countries I never thought I'd visit in my life, and to be playing in front of hundreds of thousands of fans – it's like something that I think lots of people dream of and try to achieve. But I know it won't last forever."

I jumped out of bed, lifted a corner of the bedroom curtain, and looked at the river bend. A new crack in the ice sparkled in the morning sun. I shaded my eyes and looked upstream at the sandbag wall, which was there to protect the buildings from flooding as the ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting those sandbags into place. Last week, I worked long hours with most of the town's adults, showing I could handle it. But my grandfather didn't seem to notice. With one hand still on the curtain, I looked at the half-mile stretch of steaming black water from the wood processing factory in Milltown. Fragile ice shelves were on either side, and solid ice was downstream. As I took off my pyjamas and reached for my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the far side of the river. I didn't recognize him. I frowned. He was trying to balance on an ice shelf near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and grabbed my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for the lucky chain I keep there—a silver chain my famous grandfather brought back from South America. Having this chain is better than having a famous grandfather, and only he, my mom, and I know about it. Plus, I have his diary from that journey. I keep it under my pillow and read parts of it before I sleep. I patted the chain again and headed to the kitchen. ‘Morning, Rex.’ Mom smiled as I grabbed a banana from the counter. ‘You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training. Be careful.’ ‘Thanks, Mom.’ I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into Grandpa as he came out of his room. ‘Watch where you’re going!’ he shouted. ‘Where are you going?’ ‘Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.’ As if my wetsuit didn’t make that obvious. As if he didn’t see me in my kayak every morning. Grandpa is Grandpa, and I try to ignore it when he gets angry, but it’s getting harder. ‘What’s the point of training? You didn’t win the competition,’ he said. His words stung, but I took a deep breath and counted to three. He crossed the hall and slammed the bathroom door. Mom appeared with a sympathetic smile. ‘Don’t mind him. He’s…’ ‘…not himself right now,’ I finished for her. I didn’t say he’d always been like that. But, like Mom, I try to be patient with him. When I was a child, he was my hero—from the time he showed me his photos in National Geographic. Those old photos still hang on his bedroom wall, above his dusty expedition medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own growing collection of trophies to look at and, maybe soon, my own face in National Geographic. Yet, a part of me still wants to stay devoted to him, this grumpy old man. Mom smiled. ‘At least he’s coming out of his room more. Have a good session, Rex. I admire your determination, even on cold days!’ I smiled back as I peeled my banana. ‘It’ll be warmer in South America,’ I said. ‘If I find sponsors for my expedition.’ She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I ate my banana and went downstairs. Stepping into the backyard, I hurried to the boathouse.

Mum grabbed Jess by the arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her to the study. On the table, leaning against the wall, was an unframed painting. It was clearly Grandpa's work, but different from anything he had done before and obviously unfinished. "Do you know anything about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I've never seen it before. I didn't know he was working on anything." Jess looked at the picture. A river dominated the scene; it wasn't a river she recognized and might not even be real, just imaginary. The picture was strange and shapeless, yet beautiful in a mysterious way. The riverbank was barely noticeable, just a hint of green, drawing the eye into the pale waters and towards a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people, and it felt right that way. It seemed like there was no place for living things in this distant vision. Yet, for some reason, she was fascinated, thinking of autumn coming after a long, rich summer. Mum spoke again. "It has a name." Her voice sounded too casual, too detached, revealing her excitement. Jess understood why. Grandpa never named his pictures. He just painted them and let others interpret them. Mum turned the picture over and pointed to the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud. "River Boy." The words seemed to have a strange importance to her, though she didn't know why. There was another mystery. She looked at Mum. "There is no boy." "Exactly. Strange, isn't it? For him to be so specific. Maybe he'll add the boy later. I made the mistake of asking him about it." "Mum! You should have known better." "I know, but I couldn't resist. It's such an unusual picture, especially with a name. You can guess his response." Jess didn't need to guess. She knew what Grandpa would have said. "He told you it's not up to the artist to explain a painting because each picture has its own life and language, like a poem, and we either understand it or we don't. And he said painting is hard enough without having to explain it to every idiot..." "Ignoramus, he said." "...every ignoramus what it means. And if artists had to explain their pictures to everyone, they'd never get any work done. And he said..." Mum interrupted, laughing. "Something like that. Anyway, I hoped you might know something about this painting since you seem to be a sort of muse for him." "Muse?" "Someone who inspires an artist." She knew what the word meant. Grandpa often used it when she watched him paint, but usually to say the muse wasn't being kind to him that day, or that he needed to be nice to the muse because he had a difficult part to work on. He never suggested the muse had anything to do with her. She always thought he meant some kind of goddess, not a human. And it was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, influencing someone as stubborn as Grandpa. "He doesn't need me to inspire him," she said. "He's been painting all his life."

Text: 'When I woke up this morning, I didn't plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I'm not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad's Stanley knife in my hand, the blade might have accidentally cut the carpet. I'm not saying that happened, just that it could have. I didn't wake up thinking, 'Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.' It just seemed like a good idea at the time, as things often do. Later, you wonder why you thought that, but by then it's too late. This happens to me a lot. I'm quite unlucky that way. Actually, I was trying to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It's really cute! It's small, painted white, with pink and blue flowers around the edge, and tiny glass-panelled doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in it: shepherdesses, milkmaids, and old-fashioned ladies selling balloons. I keep my collection of shells, fossils, and interesting stones there. Gran knew I always loved her corner cabinet. I was so excited when she gave it to me! But it's a corner cabinet, shaped like a triangle, so it has to stand in a corner. I only have two corners in my bedroom because it's the smallest room in the house, shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is Mum and Dad's; the one at the back is my sister Angela's; the little one over the garage is my brother Tom's; and the tiny one, like a broom cupboard, is mine. Mum says when Angela goes to University, Tom can have her room, and I can have his. And when Tom goes to University, I can choose. But since Angela is only fifteen, I'll be in my broom cupboard for years. I don't really mind; I like my little bedroom. It's cosy, like a nest. I love the sloping roof and the window at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one, and my wardrobe in the other. I tried fitting Gran's cabinet between the roof and the floor, but it was just a bit too tall. If I could only cut a couple of centimetres off the bottom... Then I had an idea. If I couldn't cut the cabinet, how about cutting a hole in the carpet? It seemed like the obvious solution. What Dad calls lateral thinking. I thought he would be pleased with me. He always tells us to 'think outside the box'. And that's exactly what I was doing!'

The novel 'The Borrowers' is about a family of tiny people who live hidden in a house, secretly taking things from the normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV version of the novel, I knew it would be difficult to meet fans' expectations. Fans of the book have strong opinions about how everything should look. I used the original drawings from the book a lot because I didn't want people to say I got it wrong. The author wanted the series to show the Borrowers' perspective, not the humans', which made filming more complex. The most important thing was getting the scale right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so if we filmed them walking across a room or going on a borrowing mission, we had to be 10 times further away than usual. When filming the human surroundings, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimeters to get the Borrowers' view; they wore out many pairs of jeans! We never raised the cameras above their height except for aerial shots. One big challenge was getting the shadows right when combining images of the tiny Borrowers with normal-sized backgrounds. We developed a special technique for this. After the series aired, the famous US film director George Lucas called to ask how I did it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with giant objects to make the actors look small. It was wonderfully surreal. When I asked them to carry things like a giant pair of scissors, they really got into it. I especially remember the coins - they were bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift. We often had to stop filming because they made the crew laugh so much. In the story, there’s a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, actors had to be swept down a tunnel with hoses and said it was so scary, they didn’t have to act at all. One important thing for me, which other directors struggled with, was getting the costumes right. I had them made from heavy canvas so they stuck out like dolls’ clothes. This made it almost impossible for the lead actress to bend in her costume. She couldn’t sit during breaks and couldn’t take the dress off as she was sewn into it every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because normal material would have looked too smooth. Unfortunately, the weather was really hot during filming. I don’t think they thanked me for my attention to detail with those costumes! Most of the action away from the Borrowers’ home had to be shot with the actors separated from their surroundings. We filmed them in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was hard for them to react to things that weren't there. I had to draw pictures of every scene to show how each should look – I did 2,000 by the end. They weren’t accurate, but they worked well enough. The budget didn’t allow for time in special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work quickly – I once shot a whole scene before realizing there was no film in the camera. But it all came together in the end, and I think the series successfully captured the magic of the books.

Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High. She looks around nervously, checking for journalists who aren’t there. I wonder how long it will take before the chaos starts. It always does. The fake smiles, the wannabe friends, the requests for free concert tickets from my dad. "Everything’s going to be fine," I reassure her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out. Then she drives off, leaving me to face this new school and situation. But this is what I wanted—to leave my old life of touring and tutors. While the band is renting here for recording, we’re staying permanently. I chose this school because I want to meet regular kids. Maybe a kid with a mom who works in an office or a dad who mows lawns. That would be so normal. 

I walk into the school’s main office. "Hi, I need my schedule, please," I say to the secretary. "Name?" she asks, not very friendly. "Desert McGraw." "Desirée?" she mishears, leaning closer. "Desert," I repeat. She seems confused but types "McGraw" on her keyboard. Luckily, few people recognize my last name because my dad uses a stage name. "What grade?" "Eleventh." "One second, it’s printing," she says, then hands me the schedule. English Literature is first period. Great, I like English. I’ll be late, though. It’s in Room 214 on the second floor. I studied the map last night to avoid looking lost. When I reach the door, the teacher is already taking roll. "Aurelio Gonzalez." "Here." I slip in quietly and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles, noticing my jeans and T-shirt. Ha! No one will suspect anything now! "Nice shoes," she whispers. I look at my expensive platforms with embroidered flowers. Oops, maybe not the best choice. "Thanks," I reply. The teacher pauses. "Desert... McGraw?" she says. "Here." She smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. After discussing the books we’ll read, she lets us socialize. All teachers should do this. "So why’d you move here?" my new friend asks. I have options. Do I say I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or the real reason, according to Dad? "We need a change, Desert," he said, "and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed." Personally, I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else choose a studio near the sand? "My dad had to relocate," I tell her. Lies work better. "What does he do?" she asks. Oh well, everyone will find out eventually. But I can pretend to be normal for now. "He’s an artist," I say, fiddling with my backpack zipper. "Cool. I’m Becca, by the way." And she doesn’t seem to care. Perfect.

Text: 'The average American teenage girl today is expected to be the Student Council president, have a part-time job, volunteer, and excel in all these areas. This is the reality for American teenagers now. Teenage boys and girls can't just go to school and stay unnoticed, because being average is no longer enough. Mediocrity is not acceptable, and lacking ambition is seen as laziness. "People, often adults, forget how much pressure teenagers face these days. We have lots of homework, tests, extra-curricular activities, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home, all while trying to maintain a social life," says teenager Kristen Loose. Despite these pressures being common in teenage life today, negative stereotypes of teenagers still exist, often spread by the media. You know the stereotypes: lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and self-absorbed. While there is some evidence of these traits, labeling the entire generation this way is not fair, according to some. "Many people assume we spend most of our time watching TV and using our cell phones," Loose says. She believes this assumption is mostly wrong. She admits to keeping her cellphone nearby most of the day, but not for trivial reasons. It's not just for texting friends; it's a tool that teens use to make their lives - and the lives of those responsible for them - easier. Students today are expected to have immediate access to the world and be reachable at all times, which can seem like a cell phone addiction. With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can now take their work with them and do homework anywhere. Instead of listening to music on the way to school, they might listen to language lessons. Schoolwork and other activities no longer stop at the school gate but require 24-hour attention from already busy teens. Many teenagers start their days around 6 a.m. or 7 a.m. and often end after midnight. Their schedule is full of school, after-school activities, family duties, and homework. Then, they must get up and do it all again the next day, with less than the recommended nine hours of sleep a night. The US National Sleep Foundation surveyed American teenagers and found that about 20 percent get the recommended nine hours of sleep. Moreover, 28 percent of teens admitted falling asleep in school about once a week due to lack of sleep. Teenager Lindamarie Olsen thinks that after all her activities, she gets about 18 hours of free time a week. With 168 hours in a week, 18 is not much. Olsen rarely spends those hours on social media or TV. Instead, she focuses on volunteer work. "I think the stereotype of teenagers is that they have a narrow view of the world, focusing only on themselves and their immediate interests," Olsen says. Despite this image, Olsen says her favorite part of the week is volunteering. "I love serving others and look forward to making a positive impact in my school and community during the week." In 20 years, who knows what the stereotype for teenagers will be, but they will still be proving it wrong and pushing the world forward. There will be another generation of students taking the world by storm, all before they leave school.'

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live near Bishop, a mountain town in the US, east of the Sierra Nevada. Over the past few years, this group has launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above Earth. This science project combines astronomy with adventure, attracting teenagers. I joined them one weekend in late spring as they prepared to launch a high-altitude balloon to record shooting stars. These occur when space rocks or metal enter Earth's atmosphere, creating a light trail. As night fell, the teenagers attached a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the balloon. Inside were a camera, an altitude instrument, and a thermometer. Two GPS trackers were outside to help find it later. A gas tank, donated by a nearby enthusiast, inflated the balloon to the size of a small car. An older boy made a seven-hour trip to get it. ‘I didn’t really mind,’ he said. For these kids, that's normal. Finally, it was time for lift-off. ‘Five, four, three, two, one,’ they chanted, and the balloon rose. Some tracked it with flashlights, lighting up the creamy orb in the moonless sky. There was a quiet, shared sense of wonder. Then the balloon vanished into the night. After the launch, most students went home, but a few stayed to watch the shooting stars. They lay on blankets, gazing at the clear sky, just four hours from Los Angeles, a bustling city of 4 million. I saw a boy fall asleep in a sleeping bag. ‘We’re the only ones talking,’ a girl whispered. ‘I know,’ another replied. A meteor streaked across the sky. As the balloon rose, air pressure decreased, and it expanded until it burst. A parachute helped the lunch box land safely. The students would find it the next day using GPS. Retrieving it wasn’t easy, but that was part of the fun. The lunch box usually landed in remote areas around Bishop. ‘Recoveries are a big part of the program,’ said the group’s leader, noting they lost only two lunch boxes in 53 launches. ‘We’ve learned about this landscape in ways we wouldn’t have otherwise.’ This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop. The recovery team had to drive south of the Sierra and back up the western side. They had to decide whether to drive or walk, as it could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or tall tree. ‘These students are native to the Eastern Sierra,’ their leader said. ‘What seems wild to some is normal to them.’ It took 11 hours to find the lunch box, which was on a flat rock in a waterfall canyon. The camera didn’t record any shooting stars, which was disappointing, but it sparked discussions about atmospheric waves over mountains. It also became another adventure story to share.

Chloe Morgan admits that science, especially Palaeontology, didn't interest her much until she was fifteen. Her interest began by chance when she helped her younger brother with a science project. She found an article about recent discoveries in Palaeontology, which fascinated her. Chloe knew then that she wanted to pursue this field. Palaeontology wasn't a common career choice for young people at that time, so I asked her about the support she received. She recalls meeting her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was already famous despite being young. Chloe was nervous at first, worried he might find her annoying, but he was patient and willing to listen, which made her feel comfortable.

I asked Chloe about how palaeontologists are portrayed in movies and TV shows. She admits that films like Jurassic Park have increased public interest in dinosaurs, but not necessarily in Palaeontology. She finds the portrayal of palaeontologists in films misleading, often showing them as eccentric geniuses or geeky figures who struggle to relate to people. Chloe explains that her job is varied, involving digging up dinosaur bones, working in labs, analyzing fossils, and writing for scientific publications. Communicating scientific findings to the public is also important to her, especially to young people, to help them understand science better.

Chloe was involved in the TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs, where she advised on the accuracy of the dinosaurs portrayed. She praises the makers for their knowledge and says she mostly checked that the dinosaurs shown lived in the same time period. The documentary attracted audiences of all ages because it depicted dinosaurs more accurately than movies like Jurassic Park.

I asked Chloe why dinosaurs continue to fascinate us. She believes they appeal to our sense of exploration and discovery. In a world that seems smaller, prehistoric creatures remind us that there is still much to discover, and Palaeontology offers a form of time travel.

Text: "Let me say this clearly: when you're on a car trip with your family, even at six years old, you probably know you're not 'there yet,' even if you keep asking 'Are we there yet?' And really, once you arrive, it's not 'there' anymore; it's 'here.' So, if you think you might be 'there,' you should ask 'Are we here yet?' No one wants to be 'there' more than the parents who hear that question repeatedly on long trips. Seriously, what are we kids complaining about? Think about it. Wouldn't you rather relax in the back seat, with nothing to do? You can watch DVDs you haven't seen, listen to music, or do puzzles, while the scenery passes by outside. In the front seat, mum or dad is there to hand out snacks, change the radio, and keep everything running smoothly. Are we there yet? I hope not. That is, until someone does something annoying—like my younger brother, Tim, putting his foot on my side of the seat. He can't do that! So I put my foot on his side. Then it's his other foot, then a hand, and soon he's in my space, and a fight starts. The driver and co-pilot separate us, telling Tim to stay in his seat. Peace returns for a while, and the scenery continues. Then, as I'm reading, I feel a breeze on my arm. The window's not open, so where's it from? Tim is blowing on me from his seat, not touching me, so he's technically not doing anything wrong. The anger rises. Tim gets scolded, and there's more swerving. Then things calm down again. Over the years, Dad has found ways to handle us in the back seat. When we ask 'Are we there yet?' he often says, 'Yes, we're here. Get out.' 'But Dad, we're on the highway!' 'Oh, maybe we're not there yet.' That keeps us quiet for a while. You know you're finally 'there' when the adults get out of the car and move away from the kids who have been bothering them. So remember: if mum and dad can still answer your question, then no, you're not there yet."

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where customers can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. They hope people will love the experience and return. Zuzi explains their motivation: "With so much technology, everyone is busy on their phones. We wanted to bring people together without screens. It's natural for us to connect and communicate." The games in their café are called 'Eurogames', known for gentle themes like farming. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, by German designer Klaus Teuber. Players build settlements and trade resources, keeping everyone engaged. This idea was developed further in 'co-operative' games, where players win or lose as a team, encouraging social interaction. Pandemic, a Eurogame by North American designer Matt Leacock, requires players to solve global problems together. Leacock was inspired by a Eurogame based on Lord of the Rings. He recalls playing it with friends and feeling a range of emotions, wanting to create a similar experience. As a child, Leacock loved board games but often felt disappointed by them. With his uncle's help, he started designing better games. Pandemic was a huge success, and its sequel added storytelling elements, similar to video games, where characters develop and the world changes. Surprisingly, the growth of video games has helped board games succeed. Video games have made gaming more common, and many people now play games on their smartphones. Ben Hogg, from a leading games company, says, "Everyone's a mobile gamer now." Video games once offered social interaction in arcades or with friends at home, but online gaming made players physically distant. Some people missed playing games with others in person. John and Zuzi's café shows that tabletop gaming is more than just fun. In our online world, games are a way to connect in real life, and this trend is likely to continue.

Jamie Scott has written and produced some of the biggest UK hits in recent years. His story shows why endurance and persistence are crucial in the music industry, even if your career starts with setbacks. Jamie's mother was a great singer and introduced him to the guitar. Growing up, he only listened to a local radio station for middle-aged people, which influenced his musical taste. He was 12 when he first heard a contemporary song. Around that time, he had to choose between tennis, which he played at a national level, and music. He spent his lunchtimes in the school music room playing the piano. Although he was good at tennis, he realized it wasn't his passion. At 17, he left school to pursue a music career. He formed a duo with a friend who was a decent guitarist but not as committed to a music career. Jamie told his parents about his dream, explaining that he wrote lyrics during economics lessons and played the piano while others played outside. His father gave him 18 months to succeed, or he would have to find a job. After some close calls with record labels, he signed with a music publisher at 19 because of one song. However, record labels wanted him as a solo artist, so he parted ways with his friend. Ultimately, he found success behind the scenes rather than on stage. After a challenging time with a UK record label, he switched to another label to release a new album, but fame and fortune didn't follow. Jamie feels that in his artist career, he was often in the wrong place at the wrong time, but as a writer, he was in the right place. Writing for others became his strength. He believes he is one of the main writers UK labels rely on to help new artists launch their careers. Sometimes, he explains to artists that aiming for chart success is nothing to be ashamed of. He asks them, "Don't you want 10 million people streaming your music next month?" He emphasizes creating songs that both he and the artist think are amazing and likely to sell well. In a world of false modesty in pop music, Jamie's straightforward desire to write number-one hits is refreshing. He isn't arrogant; he simply knows he wants to write hits and has the talent to do so. Instead of worrying about others' opinions, he focuses on his goal. "That's the endgame when I go into the studio with someone," he says. "We aim to write the best music of next year, not just what's cool. We want to create classic modern pop songs."

Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity: a big star online but probably unknown to people who don’t watch online videos of bike stunts. He is a ‘street trials cyclist’ who jumps from one difficult place, like a roof or wall, to another. These stunts are filmed and shared online. When I interview him at a BMX park on a Saturday morning, the local boys know who he is, and even older people come to praise him, calling him ‘an absolute legend’. After seeing his skills, I agree with them. Although I was skeptical at first, I am impressed by his bravery, creativity, and willingness to take risks. Before each stunt, he explains his plan, and I often doubt he can succeed. However, when I praise him, he seems indifferent and a bit downbeat. Despite his online fame, Tony says he is a reluctant celebrity. ‘I find the social side difficult. I see the value of connecting with fans, but I prefer doing things rather than talking about them.’ This is ironic because his fame comes from social media and camera technology. ‘This technology allows people like me to make a living,’ he says. ‘Sometimes I feel everyone is focused on cameras or screens, and part of me doesn’t like that.’ But he’s not complaining. The videos allow him to earn a living from what would have been just a hobby in the past. After years of interviewing top athletes, I’ve learned that two important factors turn an enthusiastic child into an elite competitor: energy and the ability to overcome emotional disappointment. These qualities may be more important than talent and help athletes persist despite failure. The riskier the sport, the more mental strength is needed. Even in the park, Tony fell a few times on what were easy but unfamiliar obstacles for him. He just got up and kept trying until he succeeded. Not everyone sees Tony as a hero. Some say he’s reckless and takes unnecessary risks. He responds, ‘Those who say this may be concerned but are not well-informed. They probably haven’t ridden a trials bike and don’t understand the sport. They don’t know the technical details and don’t realize I get expert advice to minimize risks.’ Tony is careful about the risks he takes. ‘People are different. Some never get scared and shouldn’t do these sports; it’s wise to be aware of the dangers. Others can’t overcome fear, but I’m in the group that feels fear and finds a way past it. I’m not addicted to risk and spend hours planning and preparing. Sometimes I ride around to get in the right mindset before a new stunt. I know I mustn’t lose my nerve before I jump. If I commit fully, I’m fine.’

Television presenter Helen Skelton has taken on several dangerous challenges for charity, such as running a marathon in the desert and traveling down the Amazon River in a small boat. Her latest challenge involved walking on a high wire, a long thin piece of metal, 66 meters above the ground, between two towers of an empty power station. There was no safety net, only a belt around her waist connected to another wire above. To help her balance and avoid falling, she carried a long stick weighing eight kilograms. Helen trained with an expert high-wire walker. Although she had some circus skills, she quickly learned that high-wire walking was very different. "The training was a shock," said Helen. "I didn’t realize how strong I’d need to be. Every day started at 8 am with a run up a steep hill, followed by an hour of exercises, and another hour after practicing on the wire. I also had to learn how to fall onto the wire so that if I slipped, I could continue. Every time I fell on the wire, it hurt a lot. But it was important to stay positive: if I was nervous and started shaking, so would the wire!" On the day of the challenge, it was windy, and Helen calmed herself by taking deep breaths as she moved step by step along the wire. The 150-meter walk took 15 minutes. "That was the scariest thing I’ve done," she admitted afterward. "I’m glad it’s over!" Despite this, Helen is already planning her next charity project: to reach the South Pole by ski, kite, and bike.

In 2006, Jeff Somers started a journey around the world on a penny farthing, an old bicycle with one large and one small wheel. He had already written a book about his travels in Canada in a 50-year-old car. Jeff loved motor sports and worked building racing car engines. To save money, he rode an old bicycle to work and even used it for a holiday trip to Amsterdam. ‘That trip opened my eyes,’ he says. ‘I decided to see the world by bike.’ Jeff didn’t want a regular touring bike and wanted to build one himself. ‘The craziest bicycle I could think of was a penny farthing, so I went to the museum to see how they were made.’ After two failed attempts in 2001 and 2003 due to a knee injury, he finally set off in 2006. He traveled for three years, visiting 23 countries on four continents. The highlight of his trip was reaching Tibet and seeing Mount Everest. ‘Although I met cyclists who could ride up mountains, which I couldn’t do, I never regretted my penny farthing. The further from home I got, the more amazed people were by it.’ His worst moment was when he had to drink dirty water from a stream. A serious fever left him bedridden in a hostel for ten days without medicine. He had no money for hospital bills or to return home. Despite this, Jeff now says, ‘if I could afford it, I would set off traveling again tomorrow on my penny farthing.’

I work at a university in the US, where my team and I are studying water birds, especially the American black duck. We have just started using a new tool called a 'night-vision scope' that lets us see the ducks in the dark. We are concerned about black ducks because their numbers have dropped a lot, and we are unsure if there is enough food for them on the east coast. We have plenty of information about their daytime activities, but nothing about what they do at night because we didn't have the right equipment before. This new scope gives us clear pictures, even on nights without moonlight, so we can learn more and make better decisions about protecting their habitat. The work is tough. There are four of us, each working six hours a day. We have studied ducks in different places, and I have had to take a boat to some sites and note every duck I see. The weather has been challenging – some nights are mild, but more often it's wet. It's so quiet that I need a lot of coffee to stay awake! We have only missed one day of work because the snow was too deep, even for our special snow vehicles. Still, I enjoy the challenge, especially compared to what summer will bring – hours in a lab analyzing our results. It will be hard to be indoors, but it's necessary. And I wouldn't change it for anything!

Text: 'When I tell people about my job, they can hardly believe it exists. But it's true! I spend my workdays eating chocolate. Tasting chocolate is crucial to ensure that customers receive perfect, high-quality chocolate bars from my company. Every week, I get samples from our factory to check their taste, texture, and smell. I also taste the raw materials we use, like nuts and fruit, and spend time selecting the best ones for our chocolate. Next to my office, I have a kitchen where I test and taste products I create, and I share samples with my colleagues. My kitchen is full of machines and ingredients to experiment with. It's great to have a private space to work in during the day. No two days are the same in this job. Sometimes I'm at our food lab, and other times I'm traveling abroad to buy raw materials, which can be challenging with a young family. But I love the variety and lack of routine, although the chocolate itself is my favorite part! People often ask if I get tired of chocolate. I've worked with it for a long time, and I've never felt like I didn't want to eat it. In fact, I often go home and eat more in the evening!'

Have you ever thought about what it's like to perform in a circus? Sophia Grayson is from Circus Experience, a place where young people learn circus skills. Her course is popular because it teaches many skills, like juggling, throwing and catching things like balls or even fire, and trapeze, which involves flying through the air above an amazed audience. During the year-long course, students gradually take more risks in each class, and parents can watch some classes to see their progress. Sophia explains, “For a circus career, performers need to avoid doing the same thing all the time – it’s important to keep performances fresh and exciting. If you want to succeed in the circus, you must keep practising. Another great part is making friends with other performers and learning from them. Being fit is also very important - circus artists, like athletes, train daily to stay strong. Training is crucial, but the best performers are those who want success, have imagination, and never stop improving their skills. People often think you might get injured or only work a short time each year. But the real issue is planning for the future because you can only perform while you’re young, and then you need to think about other options.” The course also includes business planning. Many former students have started businesses worldwide and are happy to share their experiences. Sophia warns, however, it’s not a profession for making money! “The work usually means not having a regular salary. It’s also competitive - but great fun!”

Text: 'You might not know her name or face, but you've probably heard her many times. Mariam Hobson is a professional backing singer. She supports the lead singer by singing in the background. Some people think backing singers aren't good enough to be lead singers. That's not true—they often need to be even better. People like Mariam are the real stars of the music industry! 'What I love about my job is that when I enter the recording studio, I never know what I'll be asked to sing,' she says. 'It could be classical, jazz, hip-hop, or rock. Or it might be a funny little tune for a radio station or an advertisement. I'm often surprised by producers' requests. Once, I was asked to sing like a fish underwater! But I never argue; I just do the job!' 'Excellent musical skills are essential for my work, plus the ability to learn quickly. There's often no printed music to refer to. I'll never forget my first experience recording background music for a film. It was very complicated because there were eight of us, each singing a different tune, and an orchestra as well. I was terrified: I knew that if I made a mistake, we would have to record everything again, which nobody likes. Recording sessions are long enough as they are.' 'One of my favorite jobs is recording for songwriters. Less experienced writers don't always know which musical range suits the female voice best. By listening to me perform their song, they can figure out how to improve it.''

Julie Deane started with only basic knowledge of fashion but has built a successful business with her 'satchels'—traditional bags used by schoolchildren. These satchels are now sold in famous stores and are popular with many celebrities. Before deciding on satchels, Julie considered various business ideas, like cake decorating and party planning, instead of just going with her first thought. Once she chose satchels, not everyone agreed with her decision. Julie says, "Many said there was no demand for them – but I was convinced." She involved her family from the beginning, working with her mother, who had no career experience but had a natural talent for business. The design inspiration came from children's storybooks. Although Julie wasn't familiar with fashion blogs, they played a key role in her success. Initially, she sold about one satchel a week. To generate interest, Julie sent satchels to fashion writers, hoping they would mention them in their blogs. They did, and interest grew, as did the speed of production. Julie now enjoys seeing which celebrity is spotted with a satchel! While other companies spend on online advertising, she uses the internet community for ideas for new styles, keeping her products fresh and exciting. There was a difficult time when another company copied her design to sell similar products, so now she ensures she trusts her production team as much as her own staff. Visitors often comment on the positive atmosphere in her offices—people love working there. There's now a new factory, and while buildings are important, it's the team that makes it a special place.

When Vicky Harmiston was a child, her parents let her and her brother Jamie choose how to spend their free time. Vicky decided to try many different sports. She was a good swimmer, and her coach thought she could become a champion. However, the swimming club was far from her home, making it hard to balance training with schoolwork. As teenagers, Jamie, who loved cycling, bought a special racing bike and started competing. Vicky found it exciting and decided to try cycling too. She says it was the best decision she ever made. Soon, she was cycling every day and doing well. The track was close to her school, so she could easily attend training sessions after school. Vicky had a successful career in track cycling and won several competitions. At 28, she retired from competitive cycling. Vicky said, ‘I loved winning competitions for years, but I started to feel tired of it all – and when the excitement stops, there’s no point. Fortunately, I found a new career.’ Vicky got a job with a charity called CycleZone. ‘We work with young people who have never enjoyed sport,’ she says. ‘First, we teach them to ride a bike. We want them to believe in themselves and their abilities. CycleZone does a great job, bringing young people together as part of a larger group.’ The charity uses celebrities to promote their work. Vicky says, ‘Some people doubt whether celebrity support is always good for a charity. They think celebrities do it for their own publicity, which can overshadow the charity’s real work. But if famous singers and actors can help, I think they should.’

Singer-songwriter Ana Ronson grew up in Ireland. Her parents weren't musicians, but there was always music at home. Her grandfather played the guitar and taught Ana and her brother. Ana first sang in front of an audience at school, but she was so nervous that her teacher had to help her off the stage. The teacher suggested she join the school theatre club to gain confidence. After some time in the club, she sang with 50 other students at a concert. A year later, her brother, who was in a band, asked her to write a song for them. She wrote her first song, Falling Stars, in just three days. She enjoyed it so much that she joined a songwriting course taught by a professional. Although she was the youngest, she knew more about music than many others. However, Ana felt the teacher didn't listen to her, so she wrote Something to Say about her frustration. She posted the song online, and it became very popular. People loved it and found new meanings in the lyrics each time they listened. Joss Alton, who owns a recording company called Isotope Music, traveled across Ireland to invite her to join Isotope. At first, Ana was unsure because she didn't know the company and didn't want to be told what to sing. Joss assured her this wouldn't happen, and soon she performed at a concert in Dublin organized by Isotope. The tickets sold out quickly, and it was a fantastic evening. Ana prefers writing songs about difficult times rather than happy ones because she feels there's more to express. One of her favorite songs is Decision, about why her brother stopped singing for a while and how it affected him. While she hopes fans enjoy her songs, her goal is to write about personal experiences that are important to her.

Last year, I went on an incredible trip—a guided group tour by boat along the west coast of Canada. It was my brother Harry’s idea. He’s a journalist, like me, and wanted to write articles about the trip. He loves boats, though that’s not something we have in common. But I had always wanted to visit the area since seeing it on TV as a child, especially because our great-grandparents lived there before moving to Europe. So, I kept asking Harry if I could join him until he finally agreed! A few days before we left, there were storms in the area we planned to visit. Fortunately, the weather forecast for our trip was for calm seas. Although there was a lot to organize, I was busy at work and didn’t have much time to think about it. But Harry assured me he’d taken care of everything, so I stopped worrying. After arriving in Canada, we joined the group, packed our limited supplies into small boats, and set off. The guide mentioned that very few people lived along that coast, and indeed, the only other living creatures we saw that first morning were dolphins and birds. We knew there were islands in the distance, but the early-morning fog made it hard to see far, so I just focused on the beautiful patterns our boat made in the water. We often stopped for hours to explore the rock pools on the beaches along the coast. They were full of amazing colored fish, many of which I didn’t recognize. It was wonderful to stop worrying about time. We never forgot lunch or dinner, though, which we all made together over campfires. When we finally fell asleep on the boats each evening, even though the beds were hard, it felt like stress-free living! When it was time to leave, I felt sad. How could I return to normal life? But I knew if I stayed, I’d miss family and friends. I was also excited to tell everyone at home about our adventures!
