My dad was a professional basketball player in Germany, just like his father before him. As a child, I often went to watch his games. You might think that this would make me love basketball, but it actually had the opposite effect. I enjoyed telling my friends how good my dad was, especially when he won, but I usually brought a book to read instead of watching the games. When I started secondary school, I was not yet a teenager but was already two meters tall. Seeing my height, my sports teacher asked if I wanted to train with the basketball team. I enjoyed the training session but felt I needed to improve my skills before playing in a real match. However, my teacher believed in me more than I did. After a few weeks, I agreed to play against another school. Having my parents watch made me nervous, but it turned out fine! For the next four years, I practiced every day and did well, even joining an adult team before moving to a special sports academy in the USA at fifteen. The coach there trains Olympic players, and it was amazing to work with him. However, I didn't enjoy being far from my parents at first. At home, I couldn't spend much time with friends because of training, so that part didn't change much. Eventually, I got used to my new life, and my English improved quickly! I turned professional at eighteen, three years after arriving in the USA. I had been taller than most professional players since I was fifteen but needed to gain weight for my height. My coach knew a team that would take me while I was still in college, so I joined them and have never regretted it.

Seven years ago, I was studying Tourism at college and needed a part-time job because my course was expensive. After considering several options, I trained to become a weekend tour guide in my home city, Chicago, USA. This job involved taking visitors around the city, and I was surprised by how much I enjoyed it. I got to see my city through the eyes of tourists, making it feel like a new experience every time. After finishing my studies, I decided to become a full-time tour guide. I thought it would be simple, but I discovered that to get a licence, I needed to know much more than I had learned. Chicago guides must answer many questions about the city, including local architecture, history, and public transport rules. After several challenging months, I gained my tour guide qualification and registered as an independent guide. Tour guiding isn't just about knowing historical facts or keeping track of your group. You need to be entertaining, tell interesting stories, and react to changing situations, like if a place is unexpectedly closed or a route changes. Tourists want to enjoy a well-organized tour without hearing about problems. I need to ensure visitors are happy with my tours, or they might post negative reviews online. Good reviews are important because they attract more customers. That's why making tours fun and stress-free is essential. My enthusiasm and energy usually result in very good reviews, and my tours are often recommended to other visitors coming to Chicago.

My name is Ella, and I am 22 years old. Last year, I went to Thailand for two weeks with my sister Josie. Although she is five years younger than me, we get along quite well. We volunteered at an elephant sanctuary, a place where people care for sick and rescued elephants. At first, I was unsure if we would connect with the other volunteers because they were much older than us. We were also nervous since it was our first time doing something like this. However, there was no need to worry in the end.

One of our main tasks at the sanctuary was to gather food for the elephants. They eat large amounts of grass and banana plants, so this took most of the day. Josie found it very hard, but seeing the elephants enjoy their meal made it worthwhile for me. We also helped wash the elephants in the river with big brushes and soap. I found this very fun, even though I got wetter than the elephants!

The part of the day I looked forward to the most was the evening. By moonlight, we led the elephants into the forest where they spent the night. All the volunteers stayed in the same house. Josie and I shared a room, so space was limited. We chose this because Josie didn’t want to be alone. It was hot and humid, especially at night, but we expected that. The meals were delicious and vegetarian, which we both prefer. After dinner, the volunteers and staff spent the evenings talking and playing games.

Now that we are back in the UK, Josie doesn’t talk much about Thailand. But if someone asks her if she enjoyed the sanctuary, she says she loved it. However, I’m not sure she is being completely honest. I think she might be a bit upset with herself for not making the most of her time there because she missed her friends too much. But when she looks back, she realizes how lucky she was to go. Maybe she will return one day—I certainly will!

I'm Gina D’Costa, and I own a flower shop in the UK. We don't just sell flowers to people for their friends or homes; we have a variety of customers. Hotels and offices often have flowers in their reception areas, and sometimes we provide flowers for business photo shoots. Once, I even decorated a castle with flowers for a wedding. It was a lot of work, but I was really proud of it. My day starts at 4 a.m. when I go to the market to buy fresh flowers. Most people are still asleep then, and my friends think I'm crazy, but I love what I do. It's often colder and darker than I'd like, but that's normal for that time of the morning, so I don't mind. The flower market is amazing, with flowers from all over the world. The sights and smells make it hard to choose. If I were choosing for myself, I'd probably only pick pink ones because it's my favorite color. But I have to remember that what I like and what customers want can be different. Not all flowers are available all year, so sometimes I can't find what customers want. I don't enjoy negotiating prices with the flower-sellers, but it's part of the job. Flowers aren't cheap, so I try to get the best price. Back at the shop, we check customer orders and arrange the flowers I bought. Then we create bouquets and calculate the cost of orders. Customers are often surprised by the prices, and I sometimes have to ask them to reconsider their choices. Some might think this is too much trouble, but I enjoy figuring out how to make the nicest arrangements for the money someone wants to spend. That's what you have to do when you're selling things – I wouldn't want any other job!

My city has a modern cinema that shows all the latest films, including many for kids on weekends. It's close to where I live, but a year ago, I felt something was missing – the chance to discuss a film in detail with others after watching it. So, with two friends, I started a film club! We decided not to rent a cinema for our screenings. Instead, we choose a different location in the city each month. For example, we used an old factory to show a film set in Antarctica. It was very cold, which created the perfect atmosphere for the film, and it was fantastic! Some places we use are even free because the owners make money by selling snacks during the film, allowing us to keep our prices low. We’re happy just to cover our costs – we’re not trying to make a profit. Each time we show a film, it gets a bit easier, especially now that we have our own reliable equipment. We also know how many tickets we've sold because everything is online – no more worries about empty seats! There’s still plenty to do, but when people of all ages tell us what a great experience they’ve had, it’s wonderful. The website has been a great help, and we’re now in contact with other film clubs across the country. We’ve visited to see how things are done in different places, but it’s always nice to return to our own club! We’ve started a blog, too, because we know most people now go online for film information, rather than read local paper reviews. We’ve also tried putting up a few posters in cafés. However, nothing is as effective as word of mouth – people recommending us to their friends. The audience loves the special activities we organize with each film – last month, it was a movie quiz, which everyone enjoyed.

Text: 'As a child, taking photographs was my favorite activity. When I was 15, I wanted to take my hobby further, so I decided to start a personal project: taking one photograph every day for a year. Many young photographers had done this before, but it seemed like a great idea to me, so I began. After a few weeks, I uploaded these photos to a website for young photographers. I wanted to create a photo diary and share my photos with others. I was surprised to find that people liked my perspective and photos. I enjoyed photographing different subjects. Then, someone suggested that my project would be better if all the photos had a common theme. I agreed and started focusing on nature scenes, especially birds and the sky. Many of my photos were black and white, which was different from other young photographers who took color photos. I sometimes doubted my project and almost quit several times. However, I trusted my instincts and became more confident in my style and choices. One day, I showed my project to my art teacher. She told me about a national photography competition for people my age. I entered some of my photos for fun. I’ll never forget when the judges told me I had won first prize; I was so happy because my project meant a lot to me. It was the first time I realized my photography might be good enough for a professional career. Now, I have my own photography studio and I’ve never regretted my career choice.'

I joined the National Youth Challenge (NYC) last year because they offered activities like camping, sailing, and public speaking, which I had never tried before. In the NYC, you can participate in various activities to challenge yourself and learn new things. There are different levels, from beginner to advanced, led by adult volunteers called 'leaders'. When you complete a level, you receive a certificate. When I first joined, my leader suggested I help organize activities at a local children’s club for two hours a week. I was unsure about this because I had attended the same club when I was eight and found it hard to make friends. I was shy, and the other children already had their own groups, so I stopped going after a few weeks. I decided to accept the challenge, mainly to earn my first NYC certificate. However, I soon wanted to spend all my free time at the children’s club. It became more important to me than just getting the certificate. After completing the challenge, the NYC leader allowed me to continue volunteering at the club because I had formed great relationships with the children. Now, I volunteer there for about four hours a week and always look forward to it. Because of my experience at the children’s club, I have decided that after finishing school in three years, I want to go to college to become a qualified youth worker, someone who works with children. This was not something I had considered before joining the club. In fact, I had never thought about my future career, and youth work had never crossed my mind. This has been my favorite part of the NYC so far, and I have improved my communication skills while helping others. I have earned several other NYC certificates now, including one for camping!

I was born in Denver, USA, and started snowboarding when I was eight. My dad took me to a mountain resort about two hours from Denver. The hill looked very steep, so my dad had to convince me to try snowboarding. I was too young to think about snowboarding myself, but my dad loved it and wanted me to enjoy it too. He made it look easy, and eventually, I managed well. After that, I quickly developed a love for the sport and improved my skills. I started competing at ten. Some people enter many competitions and get bored, but my love for competing and winning has grown stronger as I’ve gotten older, which motivates me to push myself. I like not having a fixed plan, and sometimes it works out well, like when I became the first female to score a perfect 100 at a local competition. I wasn’t sure I’d try the jumps that got me this score until I started. That achievement boosted my confidence in my abilities. In the summer, I focus on training and studying since there’s no snow. I train daily, but it’s nice not to follow a strict diet like in winter. I also spend a lot of time with friends. It helps me cope with not being able to do what I love and am good at. I have to think about my future. Snowboarding is a big part of my life, but I also want another option in case I don’t succeed as a professional snowboarder or get injured. I’m considering becoming a doctor if I can balance it with my active life. I can’t imagine getting tired of snowboarding, but I know I can’t do it forever.

When I was fifteen, I wanted everything my friends had and never thought about the future. For example, I didn't know what I wanted to do after school. One day, my best friend got a new phone for her birthday, and I wanted one too. My parents said I could have it only if I paid for it myself, so I decided to work part-time and save money. I learned a valuable lesson from this. I worked every Saturday in a café, but I didn't enjoy it. My parents suggested I start my own small business. I had seen my mum making necklaces, so I asked if I could try it. I found it easier than I expected, even though it looked complicated when I watched Mum. My friends thought it was boring, but I liked the idea. Mum showed me how to make something nice at home with simple tools and materials. I sold my first jewellery pieces to friends and family. They said they loved them, but I thought they were just being nice. To see if others would like them, I rented a market stall with my mum. Many tourists visit my town, and they bought my jewellery as gifts. Soon, we got calls from people all over the country wanting to buy more. They thought we were a big company, but it was just the two of us at a market stall! That's when I realized it could work, and I decided to create a website. Since then, I've made thousands of pounds through my business, mostly online, but we still have our stall too. It's been a lot of fun so far.

When Janine Stuart was just 13, she wrote a novel called Being Amelia, which became a bestseller. The book is partly based on Janine’s own life. In an interview, Janine explained, "Because of my father’s job, my family moved around a lot, so I got good at making new friends. I know what it’s like to be the new student in a class, and that helped me write about Amelia, the main character, starting at a new school. Some of the funniest parts of the book are about Amelia’s home life, especially her relationship with her older brother. Since I’m an only child, I had to use my imagination for that."

Janine began writing her novel one summer when she was bored at home. Her mother had always wanted to be a published author, and her teachers encouraged her to write, so it seemed natural for Janine to start writing. The year before, she had won first prize in a short story competition on a young writers’ website. Because of this, when Janine finished Being Amelia and sent it to a publisher, they were eager to read it. They loved it, and a year later, Janine’s novel was available in bookshops.

One review of Being Amelia notes that even though the cover shows happy teenagers, the characters face some tough challenges, which makes them believable. The reviewer says that although Janine is young and her novel isn’t very long, she has shown she is a better writer than many bestselling authors. Janine is still getting used to being famous: "At first, I hid when people recognized me in the street, but now it’s OK. I’d like to give advice to other young writers, but they need to find what works for them. For me, spending time with friends gives me ideas to write about!"

I'm Tom, I'm fifteen years old, and three years ago my family and I moved to a castle on a small island. It all began when my father was offered the job of managing the castle. He works for an organization that takes care of historical buildings and keeps them open to the public. He was excited because he thought he might not get such a great opportunity again, but it took some time for the rest of us to agree that Dad should take the job. We were mainly thinking about what life on the island would be like – we knew the castle might not be as comfortable as our cozy home just across the water, and there was no school. Once we moved, though, we quickly adapted to island life. The castle isn't particularly beautiful, but our apartment in it is comfortable. The island feels very lively in summer because it attracts many visitors, and there are often parties on the beach. In winter, we only see the other families who live on the island, and there aren't as many teenagers among them as I had hoped. The adults all support each other and help with repairs on the island, which often involves a lot of hard work. The biggest change for me was traveling by boat every day back to my old school. I was excited about going on stormy days when there are huge waves – but the ferries don't run then! And I've learned that if I miss the bus to the harbor after school, I also miss the last ferry home, which is worrying. So when schoolmates come home to stay with me, I'm always telling them to hurry up! But we often get the most fantastic views, like when the sun sets over the sea. Some days, though, it's so foggy that you can't see anything, then within hours, it's brilliant sunshine again – it still seems amazing when that happens, even after living here all this time. Of course, we do get terrible storms, and I sometimes wonder if the castle is strong enough to avoid getting damaged. But then I remind myself it's been here for centuries – and it's still standing!

I live in a house surrounded by beautiful countryside in Scotland. I’ve always loved nature and wild animals, and six years ago, I started a new hobby – birdwatching! I went to some mountains in northern Scotland with my family, where we saw many birds in their natural environment. I spent hours watching them with my parents, who taught me how to tell different species apart and find the best places to see them. It was amazing, and after returning home, I joined a local young birdwatchers’ club. My goal is to see 200 different bird species, and I’m close to achieving that because on family holidays abroad, I’ve seen birds from other countries too. We always look for places with group birdwatching activities, so I can add new birds to my list! I’ve been to Egypt, and last summer we went to South America, where I hoped to see my 200th species. I wasn’t too disappointed when it didn’t happen, as I’ve learned that patience is important in this hobby. I posted a video online about this challenge, and many teenagers found it fascinating and commented on it. When my teachers saw it, they asked me to give a presentation about birdwatching at school. I didn’t feel nervous until just before I was introduced and walked onto the stage. I knew I’d remember what to say and had some notes to help me, but the whole school and all my friends were watching! I only relaxed when it was over, and the teachers said I’d prepared well and they’d really enjoyed it. I might even do another one next year! I’m lucky to live in the countryside. I understand why many teenagers in cities might not think of becoming birdwatchers, but there are actually plenty of birds to see, especially in places with lots of green areas. I also think birdwatching clubs should try to get more young people interested in this hobby. Everyone needs to connect with nature, whatever their age, and it doesn’t have to cost much money.

I started playing football when I was 7 years old. I would rush home from school to play with other kids. I loved it, and soon I became a decent player. However, my family knew I often got excited about new hobbies and then lost interest, so they probably thought the same would happen with football. But it didn’t. I was already dreaming of playing football professionally when I grew up. The chance came sooner than I expected. I played in local tournaments, and one referee noticed I was talented. He asked the manager of a professional women’s club to watch me play. She was impressed and invited me to join her club. I couldn’t believe it at first—I didn’t know young girls could join women’s clubs. But I started training regularly with a big club at 13. I improved a lot. Still, some people doubted I’d become a star player, which upset me. But my coach encouraged me to be myself and believe in myself. He even let me play in a championship match earlier than I expected! I ran harder than ever—I didn’t want to be blamed for losing. By luck, I scored the winning goal. Despite the large crowd, I could hear my coach cheering me on, and after the match, the team carried me around the pitch. It was fantastic! Since then, I’ve scored many more winning goals. Next month, my coach and I are organizing a football tournament in my area. The goal is to get teenagers interested in football and let them meet other players from my club. It will show them the professional environment and encourage them to believe they can play for a top team if they work hard. My advice to them will be the same as my coach’s advice to me—you’ll have good times, but be ready for bad times too. I’ve had very few bad times, though, so I’ve been lucky!

One of the most interesting changes in higher education in the UK and worldwide is encouraging students to get involved in research early in their studies. This shift recognizes that research is not just for famous scholars or scientists at top universities. Instead, it is a natural and essential way to build knowledge and skills. Research skills are valuable not only in your studies but also in your future job, as they help you think about the world and approach your work. As a student, you contribute to knowledge by creating it, not just repeating it. This involves asking questions like Why? How? When? What does this mean? What if things were different? These questions are at the heart of research.

Research can range from groundbreaking, complex studies by highly trained experts to everyday inquiries that involve careful work and thoughtful questions about issues and practices. Most students have been researchers in some way, asking questions and investigating since their early days in school or work. You have used research skills when planning a holiday, growing plants, fixing things, training a pet, or shopping online.

In college and higher education, having an enquiring mind, identifying problems, critically evaluating information, and creating your own responses are expected learning activities. Some students may find this challenging, especially if they come from cultures where knowledge is seen as fixed and learned by listening to authority figures. In the UK, US, much of Europe, and Australasia, questioning established knowledge and authorities is encouraged.

Critical thinking is crucial in research. While the research of others is useful, we must not just accept it as fact. We need to engage with it, test it, and determine if it is logical and supported by evidence. We should not rely uncritically on information given to us in reading or verbally.

Cities have always been centers of intellectual activity. In the 18th century, people in London gathered in coffee houses to discuss topics like chemistry and politics. In modern Paris, artists like Pablo Picasso talked about modern art in cafés. However, living in a city is not always easy. The same London coffee houses that encouraged discussion also spread diseases like cholera, and Picasso eventually moved to the countryside. While cities can inspire creativity, they can also be overwhelming and unnatural. Scientists are now studying how city life affects our brains, and the findings are concerning. Although city life is known to be tiring, new research shows that it can also dull our thinking. One major issue is the lack of nature, which is surprisingly good for the brain. Studies show that hospital patients recover faster when they can see trees from their windows. Even brief views of nature can improve brain function by giving us a break from the busy city life. This research is important because, for the first time in history, most people live in cities. Instead of open spaces, we are in crowded urban areas with many strangers. These unnatural environments affect our mental and physical health and change how we think. Walking down a busy street, our brains have to manage many things: distracted people, traffic, and the confusing city layout. This constant need to focus drains our mental energy. Cities are full of stimuli, requiring us to constantly shift our attention, which is tiring. In contrast, natural settings don't demand as much mental effort. This idea is called attention restoration theory, developed by psychologist Stephen Kaplan. He suggested that being in nature can restore our attention. Natural environments capture our attention without causing stress, unlike city noises like police sirens. This allows our minds to relax and recharge. Long before scientists studied this, philosophers and landscape architects warned about the effects of city life and sought ways to include nature in urban areas. Parks like Central Park in New York offer an escape from city life and can quickly improve brain function. While people try various methods to boost cognitive performance, like energy drinks or office redesigns, few are as effective as a walk in nature. Despite the mental challenges of city life, cities continue to grow. Even in the digital age, they remain hubs of intellectual activity. Research from the Santa Fe Institute shows that the same urban features that challenge our attention also promote innovation. The concentration of social interactions in cities drives creativity. Just as 18th-century London was a center of intellectual breakthroughs, modern cities like Cambridge, Massachusetts, are successful creative hubs. Less crowded cities may produce less innovation over time. The challenge is to reduce the negative effects of city life while keeping its benefits. As the saying goes, sometimes people feel, "I'm sick of the trees, take me to the city!"

**Where is the Mind?**

Where should we look for the mind? It might seem obvious: thinking happens inside our heads. Today, we have advanced brain imaging to support this. However, I believe the study of the mind shouldn't stop at the skin or skull. Evidence from prehistory to now shows that objects, not just neurons, are part of human thinking. Archaeology reveals that stone tools, ornaments, engravings, clay tokens, and writing systems have influenced human evolution and the mind. So, what is outside the head might still be part of the mind.

It's easy to see why the mind and brain are often seen as the same. Most of our knowledge about the mind comes from studying people in isolation from their usual surroundings. This is practical for neuroscientists using brain-scanning machines. But it often overlooks that much of our thinking happens outside our heads. I don't deny the brain's role in cognition, but I suggest that the mind extends into culture and the material world.

This idea is central to my Material Engagement Theory (MET). MET explores how objects become part of our thinking, like making symbols from clay or using stones as tools. It also looks at how these interactions have changed over time and what that means for our thinking. This approach offers new insights into what minds are and how they work.

Consider a blind person with a stick. Where does their self begin? The stick and the person form a unit, showing how minds and objects are connected. The stick helps the blind person 'see' through touch, becoming part of their body. This example highlights the flexibility of the human mind, which adapts by incorporating new tools.

I see the human mind as an ongoing project, always evolving. Throughout history, tools—from stone tools to the internet—have been pathways for understanding the world, not barriers. Humans use tools to explore and learn, unlike other animals. This unique trait explains why humans create things and how these things shape our minds. I call this metaplasticity—our minds change as they interact with the material world.

MET offers a new way to understand how material culture, from ancient tools to modern technology, shapes and transforms our thinking. While "mind-changing technology" sounds futuristic, humans have been using it since our species began.

Photography has greatly influenced civilization, especially in the United States, where it quickly became part of the culture. It has been used in many areas, from science and industry to art and entertainment. Historians consider photography to be one of the US's most significant contributions to the visual arts. To understand its impact, we need to look at its beginnings in the mid-19th century.

Photography was appealing for several reasons. First, it was a mechanical process that matched the growing interest in technology, reflecting a national mindset that embraced change. Like steam power and railroads, photography made the world feel smaller by bringing distant sights into people's homes. Second, the camera was a tool for self-representation, allowing people to create and share images of themselves in a country where identities were constantly evolving. Third, it helped families create records of themselves, even if these were somewhat idealized. Lastly, photography's realism aligned with the US artists' focus on everyday life.

Photographs draw attention to what the photographer wants us to see, and because they are made by machines, they are seen as objective records of reality. However, they also reflect the photographer's perspective, adding a subjective element. While photographs are often called a 'universal language,' their meaning can be complex. Images are influenced by the context in which they are presented, such as captions or their placement in media. To understand a photograph historically, we must consider its purpose and how it was first viewed. The same image can have different meanings in different contexts.

In recent decades, artists like Andy Warhol have used photographs in their work, showing that photography is not separate from painting but an essential part of it. Photographic vision has become integral to our understanding of representation in art.

In 1890, William James, an American philosopher and one of the founders of modern psychology, described psychology as the "science of mental life." This definition is still useful today. We all have a mental life, so we have some understanding of what this means. Although the concept can be studied in animals like rats and monkeys, it remains somewhat elusive. James, like most psychologists, was mainly interested in human psychology. He believed it involved basic elements: thoughts and feelings, a physical world in time and space, and a way of knowing these things. This knowledge is personal and private, coming from our own thoughts, feelings, and experiences, and may not always align with scientific facts. We often act as amateur psychologists, offering opinions on complex psychological issues, like brainwashing or why people behave in certain ways. Problems arise when people understand things differently. Formal psychology provides methods to decide which explanations are most likely correct in a situation. Psychologists help us distinguish between subjective thoughts, which can be biased, and scientific facts. Psychology, as defined by James, is about the mind or brain. However, psychologists do not fully understand the brain's role in our hopes, fears, and behaviors. It is difficult to study the brain directly, so psychologists learn more by studying behavior and forming hypotheses about internal processes. A challenge in psychology is that scientific facts should be objective and verifiable, but the mind's workings are not directly observable. They must be inferred from behavior. Psychology is like solving a crossword puzzle, involving evaluating and interpreting clues. These clues come from careful observation, accurate measurement, and logical analysis. Complex interactions are common in psychology, requiring sophisticated techniques and theories. Psychology aims to describe, understand, predict, and control or modify processes. Achieving these goals helps us understand our experiences and apply findings to real life. Psychological research has been useful in areas like teaching children to read, designing safer machines, and helping emotionally distressed people communicate better. Although psychological questions have been discussed for centuries, scientific investigation began only about 150 years ago. Early psychologists used introspection, or reflecting on one's own experience, to answer questions. They aimed to identify mental structures, but introspection has limitations. As Sir Francis Galton noted, it only reveals a small part of brain activity. William James compared it to trying to see darkness by quickly turning on a light. Modern psychologists prefer to base theories on careful observations of behavior rather than personal reflections.

In a warehouse in a business park in Michigan, USA, there is a unique place known as the Museum of Failed Products. This museum, owned by a company called GfK, displays products that were taken off the market because they didn’t sell well. You can find unusual items like A Touch of Yogurt shampoo and Breakfast Cola there. Carol Sherry, who runs the museum, believes each product tells a sad story about the designers, marketers, and salespeople involved. Surprisingly, the museum is a successful business. Many companies don’t keep their own collections of failed products, so executives visit the museum to learn from these mistakes.

The museum was started by Robert McMath, a former marketing professional, who wanted to create a ‘reference library’ of consumer products. He began collecting new products in the 1960s, not specifically failures. However, he discovered that most products fail, so his collection naturally became filled with unsuccessful items. This reflects a culture of optimism where people often overlook potential failures. Marketers might even invest more money in failing products to try to boost sales and save face, rather than understanding what went wrong.

This optimistic mindset is also common in the self-help industry, where ‘positive visualization’ is popular. The idea is that imagining success makes it more likely to happen. Neuroscientist Tali Sharot suggests that humans are naturally inclined to be overly optimistic, which might have helped our ancestors survive. Her research shows that well-balanced people often overestimate their ability to influence events, unlike those with depression who have a more realistic view.

Psychologist Gabriele Oettingen has studied whether positive fantasies about the future are effective. Her research found that thinking too much about success can actually reduce motivation. For example, people who imagined having a successful week at work often achieved less.

Psychologist Carol Dweck explains that our reaction to failure depends on our beliefs about ability. People with a ‘fixed mindset’ think ability is innate and see failure as proof they lack talent. In contrast, those with a ‘growth mindset’ believe ability develops through effort and view failure as a chance to improve. Dweck compares this to weight training, where muscles grow stronger after being pushed to their limits. Having a growth mindset is a more positive way to live, regardless of success.

Text: 'It's well-known that sports teams have an advantage when they play at home. But why is that? Many people think they know the answer, but professional sports are changing rapidly, and what we once believed is now being questioned. Two main factors challenge the traditional view of home advantage: science and money. Sports scientists are exploring what helps players perform at their best, leading to many theories about home advantage. Meanwhile, financial interests question if home advantage should matter at all. If players are paid well, shouldn't they perform well anywhere? 

What about the fans? Would it matter if Manchester United played some home games in the Far East to reach fans there? It would matter to British fans, who believe their support is crucial for the team's success. Fans often think their cheering leads to goals, but they forget the times when their support didn't result in success. However, one fan belief is supported by science: home fans influence referees. In an experiment, referees watched a match with and without crowd noise. Those who heard the noise were less likely to call fouls against the home team. This suggests referees avoid decisions that would anger the home crowd.

Studies show that home advantage has decreased in major sports, but not as much as expected. For example, in the 1890s, home teams in England's Football League won 70% of the points, compared to 60% today. Travel used to be difficult, but now players travel in comfort, and stadiums are more similar. Despite these changes, home advantage varies by sport. Basketball has the highest home advantage, followed by football, while baseball has the least. This might be because baseball focuses more on individual matchups, while basketball relies on teamwork. Playing at home boosts team confidence, which is crucial in team sports.

Another factor is the players' testosterone levels, which are higher before home games. This might relate to a natural instinct to defend home territory. In the recent Rugby World Cup, underdog teams won at home by showing determination and refusing to be intimidated, demonstrating home advantage. As one referee said, 'It’s the law of the jungle out there.'

Text: "‘The more I practise, the luckier I get,’ said golfer Gary Player about fifty years ago. This saying is famous among athletes and coaches. The quote's origin is debated, with claims for other golfers too. Its meaning is also puzzling. Player didn't mean luck literally; he meant, ‘The more I practise, the better I get.’ This idea relates to the nature-nurture debate: is talent born or made? However, it's not really a balanced debate. The focus has been more on nurture, the idea that practice is more important than natural talent. This view is supported by psychologist Anders Ericsson, who proposed that 10,000 hours of practice can make anyone an expert. His theory inspired books like Malcolm Gladwell’s Outliers, which argue that practice is key. But, as David Epstein argues in his book, this is not always true. Epstein points out a flaw in studies of excellence: they often only look at successful people. He explores why some people have certain abilities and others don't, considering factors like environment, support, and determination. Epstein travels worldwide, from Kenya to Sweden, and even to Alaska, where he learns that in sled dog races, the dogs' drive might be genetic. This suggests that determination might also have a genetic component. Epstein distinguishes between 'hardware' (nature) and 'software' (nurture) and believes both are needed for elite athletes. He acknowledges the role of training and environment, suggesting that if Usain Bolt had grown up in the US, he might have been a basketball player. However, Epstein also highlights cases where genetics are crucial. He examines race and gender, asking why men and women compete separately if only practice matters. Sometimes, the simplest questions are the most important."

A recent international report shows that many children in wealthy countries feel lonely and unhappy. Jay Griffiths asks why this is happening. In her book, "Kith," she suggests that children are spending too much time indoors, in front of screens, and have lost touch with nature. This, she argues, is the main issue. This idea is supported by other discussions about modern childhood. A follow-up study interviewed children and found that many would be happier if they could spend more time outside. Adults over 40 often remember their own childhoods fondly, recalling how they spent time exploring outdoors, which they believe was healthier than the protected lives of children today. However, they often forget that they are the ones who have created these protective environments for their children, avoiding risks like playing in old sheds.

Griffiths' book includes strong arguments about the fear of outdoor dangers and how it benefits the toy and gadget industry, which sells products to keep children entertained indoors. She also criticizes trends like giving medication to restless children or making them wear goggles for playground games. While some of these regulations might be exaggerated, Griffiths expresses her frustration clearly and passionately. She also discusses childhood freedoms and restrictions, from fairy tales to school rules.

Despite her appealing arguments, Griffiths sometimes takes her ideas too far and ignores important counter-arguments. For example, she compares modern treatment of children to a form of racism, which seems extreme. Griffiths is a romantic when it comes to children, often seeing them in an idealized way that might not match reality. She believes children should have the freedom to explore and take risks, arguing that they need small accidents to learn how to avoid bigger ones later. However, she doesn't explain how to ensure these accidents are "the right size." Additionally, not all children may want the adventurous lifestyle she promotes. Some children are naturally more cautious and prefer staying at home. Perhaps the real issue is forcing all children into the same mold, whether keeping them inside or pushing them outside.

I am a research bio-psychologist with a PhD, so I have spent a lot of time in school. I am good at solving problems in my work and life, but this skill doesn't come from my schooling. Most life problems can't be solved with complex formulas or memorized answers from school. They need judgment, wisdom, and creativity, which come from life experiences. For children, these experiences come from play. My recent research focuses on the importance of play for children's development. All young mammals, including humans, play, and those with more to learn play the most. Carnivores play more than herbivores because hunting is harder to learn than grazing. Primates play more than other mammals because their lives depend more on learning than on instincts. Children, who have the most to learn, play more than any other young primates when they can. Play is how mammals, including humans, have always learned. The most important skills for children to live happy, productive, moral lives can't be taught in school. These skills are learned through play. They include creativity, getting along with others, cooperating, and controlling impulses and emotions. Creativity is crucial for economic success. We don't need people to follow instructions like robots or do routine calculations. We need people who can ask new questions and solve new problems. If we can develop thinkers who anticipate obstacles, we will have a strong workforce. This requires creative thinking. A creative mind is a playful mind. Geniuses are adults who keep and build on their childlike creativity. Albert Einstein said school almost destroyed his interest in math and physics, but he regained it after leaving school. He called his innovative work 'combinatorial play.' He developed his theory of relativity by imagining himself chasing a sunbeam. We can't teach creativity, but we can suppress it with schooling that focuses on imposed questions with one right answer. More important than creativity is the ability to get along with others, care for them, and cooperate. Children are born wanting to play with others, and through play, they learn social skills, fairness, and morality. Play is voluntary, meaning players can quit anytime. If you can't quit, it's not play. Players know they must keep others happy to continue the game. This makes play the most democratic activity. School has become more demanding: breaks are shorter, homework has increased, and pressure for high grades has grown. Outside school, adult-directed sports have replaced spontaneous games. 'Play dates' with adults have replaced unsupervised neighborhood play, and adults now intervene instead of letting children solve their own problems. These changes have been gradual but significant. They result from social factors like parents' fears, experts warning about dangers, declining neighborhoods, and the belief that children learn more from adults than from each other. Our children don't need more school; they need more play. If we care about our children and future generations, we must reverse the trend of the past fifty years. We must give childhood back to children. They must be allowed to play and explore to grow into strong adults ready for an unpredictable future.

In many countries, more people in their twenties are using social media to find jobs. Platforms like Twitter and LinkedIn allow direct contact with potential employers, similar to standing outside an office with a "hire me" sign. However, this access also increases the risk of mistakes. For example, a young jobseeker in the US contacted a senior marketing executive on LinkedIn, hoping to use her contacts to find a job. The executive, offended by this request from a stranger, rejected him and sent a sarcastic note that went viral. Many who saw the note online were shocked, and the executive might regret her harsh tone. Yet, this incident highlights the importance of using social media carefully for professional purposes. Social media can be risky for job seekers who misuse it, and many are making mistakes. 

Ironically, social media has been central to the social lives of twentysomethings for years. For my generation, it was a way to escape from parents and teachers, a place to impress and experiment. It was often based on fantasy, where you could have long conversations online and ignore the person in real life. You could change your image overnight with a new Facebook profile picture or song. But using social media for professional networking is different, and some young people struggle to see the difference. We learned to be bold and confident online, which might explain why some still think this works. Just because many people liked your Facebook posts doesn't mean you can impress employers on LinkedIn. We need to understand that our teenage social media skills don't apply in the professional world, and we must meet employers' expectations to succeed.

One common complaint from employers is that young job seekers are too familiar and seem arrogant on professional networking sites. This reinforces the stereotype of an "entitled generation." In reality, many young people are desperate to find jobs, which is why they turn to social media. This perceived arrogance can harm their job prospects, even if they have the skills and motivation to be valuable employees. So, how should you contact someone on a professional networking site? First, clearly explain who you are and what you can offer them, like doing research or helping in some way. This approach increases your chances of a positive response. Avoid sending impersonal, generic messages, and keep a humble tone to avoid offending the recipient. Remember, social media can help you make useful contacts, but it requires careful use to avoid closing doors.

Text: 'Predicting the future of newspapers is very difficult. If you look at the numbers, newspapers seem to be in trouble. Since 2000, the circulation of most UK national newspapers has dropped by a third to half. In the USA, the Pew Research Centre reports that newspapers are now the main news source for only 26% of people, compared to 45% in 2001. Many people predict that printed newspapers will disappear within 15 years. However, history shows that old media often survive. In 1835, a New York journalist claimed that books and theatre were outdated, but theatre survived alongside newspapers, cinema, and television. Radio has thrived in the TV era, and cinema has competed with videos and DVDs. Even vinyl records have become popular again, with online sales increasing by 745% since 2008. Newspapers were once new media too, but they only became the main news source in the mid-19th century with the steam press, railway, and telegraph. This was also when people started to believe that everything is constantly changing and we need regular updates, a concept unfamiliar in medieval times. Now, we expect change. In medieval times, people only noticed the changing seasons and unexpected disasters like famine or disease. Journalism as a profession barely existed before the 19th century, and there was no clear reason for regular news updates. Regular newspaper publication can be limiting. Online news allows readers to check updates based on their interests. Search engines and algorithms help personalize news. Online news can provide minute-by-minute updates and correct errors quickly. There are no space limits, and full documents can be accessed. This is very different from traditional newspapers. However, online news often focuses on being first and creating excitement, rather than spreading understanding. In medieval times, news was shared in markets or taverns, mixed with rumors and misunderstandings. In some ways, we are returning to that. Newspapers have not always been good at explaining how the world works. They might face extinction, or they might find a way to help us understand our complex world.'

If humans were truly comfortable under the moon and stars, we would enjoy the darkness, seeing the midnight world as clearly as many nocturnal animals do. However, we are creatures of the day, with eyes suited for sunlight. This is a fundamental part of our biology, even if we don't often think of ourselves this way. This explains why we have transformed the night by filling it with artificial light. This control is similar to damming a river, bringing benefits but also causing problems known as light pollution. Light pollution happens because of poor lighting design, which lets artificial light spread into the sky instead of focusing it downward. This unwanted light changes the natural darkness, affecting the light levels and rhythms that many living things, including humans, have adapted to. Wherever artificial light enters the natural world, it impacts life processes like migration, reproduction, and feeding.

For most of human history, the idea of 'light pollution' would have been meaningless. Imagine approaching London on a moonlit night around 1800, when it was the world's largest city. Nearly a million people lived there, relying on candles, torches, and lanterns. Only a few homes had gas lighting, and public gaslights wouldn't appear for another seven years. From a distance, you would have smelled London before seeing its faint glow. We've illuminated the night as if it were empty, but that's far from true. Among mammals alone, many species are nocturnal. Light is a strong biological force, attracting many species. It's so powerful that scientists describe songbirds and seabirds as being 'captured' by searchlights or gas flares, circling until they drop. Birds migrating at night often collide with brightly lit buildings, with young birds on their first journey being most affected. Some birds, like blackbirds and nightingales, sing at odd hours due to artificial light.

It was once thought that light pollution only affected astronomers, who need a clear night sky for their work. While most of us don't need an unobstructed view of the stars, we do need darkness. Ignoring this need is pointless. Darkness is as crucial for our health as light; disrupting our internal rhythms can lead to health issues. The regular cycle of waking and sleeping reflects the Earth's light cycle. These rhythms are so essential that disturbing them is like changing our center of gravity. Ultimately, humans are as trapped by light pollution as frogs near a brightly lit highway. Living in our own glare, we have disconnected from our evolutionary and cultural heritage—the stars and the natural day-night cycle. Light pollution makes us lose sight of our true place in the universe, forgetting our scale, which is best understood under a deep night sky with the Milky Way overhead.

The founder of a large international company recently announced that his company will stop tracking employees' paid holiday time. This decision was inspired by an internet company that has a similar policy. The founder said the idea came from an email from his daughter, which seemed like it was written by his media team. Ignoring the way the announcement was made, we should ask: is this idea practical? The internet company and the multinational corporation are very different. The internet company has 2,000 employees and offers one service, while the multinational has 50,000 employees and many different services, like finance, transport, and healthcare. The idea of "take as much time off as you want, as long as it doesn't harm the business" might work better in a smaller company where employees know each other's workloads. In a large company, it's harder to be sure that taking time off won't affect the business or your career. No matter how much you prepare before a holiday, work will pile up while you're away. This is just how taking leave works. Employees might feel guilty about taking time off, leading to stress and lower productivity. There could also be pressure from colleagues about who takes time off and when. In the corporate world, there's a culture of working late, which could lead to a "no holiday" culture in a company with unlimited leave. Without the security of statutory leave, employees might feel they can't take the time they need, fearing they look lazy. This could result in employees not taking their entitled leave or sticking to their statutory rights, making the policy pointless. Modern technology blurs the line between work and free time, as employees can receive work messages anytime. The internet company started their unlimited leave policy because employees questioned how the new way of working fit with the old time-off policy. If employers can't track work hours accurately, why apply an outdated standard to time off? However, without set working hours, all hours could become work hours. Employees might feel their work hours are being watched, leading them to self-monitor, which can be harmful. Employment laws exist to ensure workers get enough rest for their health. The benefits of the unlimited leave policy, like increased morale and productivity, can happen without affecting worker well-being. I doubt that allowing unlimited holidays is the real goal or likely result of this policy.

Journal-based peer review is the process where experts in a field evaluate a scientific research paper before it is published. It is seen as a way to ensure the quality of research by preventing flawed papers from being published. This process can delay publication by up to a year. Is this delay worth it to ensure trustworthy research? The answer is both yes and no. Examining these issues reveals much about the current state of scientific publishing, which is changing. While I still support some form of review before publication, I notice a shift happening. The increasing use of preprints—drafts of papers shared online without peer review—is a key part of this change. Preprints allow for the quick sharing of new research so it can be read, critiqued, and built upon. Publishing in journals has become more about gaining recognition and advancing careers, which can distort the motivations of authors and reviewers. The competition for spots in top journals encourages scientists to do their best work, but it also leads to cutting corners, as stories without inconvenient data are more likely to be published. Reviewers now often decide if a paper is suitable for a journal based on its newsworthiness rather than its scientific quality. These issues are known, but few are willing to change the system. However, as biologist Ron Vale suggested, preprints might offer a solution because they don't require a major change from the norm. Although preprints have existed for twenty years, they are not widely used. This is partly due to scientists' conservative nature and the misconception that journals won't accept papers posted as preprints. There is also a fear that publishing without peer review could lead to 'junk science,' but this hasn't happened yet. Authors know that preprints are open to critique by a global community. Psychology professor Tanya Elks shared her experience: her paper critiqued another paper, which traditional journals handle poorly. With preprints, the original authors could respond, and all comments were public, allowing readers to judge the arguments' quality. Even if journals reject the paper, the preprint and comments remain available, so the work isn't wasted. Preprint archives allow for global scientific discussions that were once private. They can also be a place for sharing negative results, which journals often overlook. Preprints increase how often papers are read and cited, showing their effectiveness in spreading research. By using the internet's openness and the collaborative spirit of the scientific community, preprints can help focus attention on the research itself, not just where it is published.

When I ask my literature students to define a poem, they often say things like "a painting in words." These answers usually don't satisfy any of us. One day, I asked a group to pick an object and write two paragraphs: one describing it scientifically, and another from the object's perspective, titled "Poem." Here's what one student wrote:

Poem: I may look strange or scary, but I'm a device that helps people breathe. I'm only used in emergencies and even then for a short time. Most people will never need me.

The object? An oxygen mask. This unusual choice helped the class understand how poetry works in a unique way. The exercise led to laughter and meaningful discussion.

When I was in school, poetry often seemed confusing to me. I saw each poem as a puzzle that blocked true understanding and emotion. After school, many people find poetry less engaging. Occasionally, you come across a poem, and it stands out because it's not continuous prose. It almost challenges you to read it, and often you feel let down by its simplicity or because it’s hard to understand at first. Still, you feel good for trying.

What do we expect from poems? Aren't they supposed to hold deep emotions, beautiful images, thoughtful reflections, or sharp wit? The answer might seem to be yes. But for tears, we turn to movies; for information or sharp critique, we read online articles. Novels offer us worlds to escape to, paintings give us visual pleasure, and music – well, nothing quite matches the mix of lyrics, instruments, and melody.

However, one thing a poem can offer is ambiguity. Everyday life, unlike reading sentence by sentence, is full of it. But these thoughts still don't define what a poem truly is. If you search online for "poem," it redirects to "poetry": "a form of literary art using aesthetic and rhythmic qualities of language." This is academic language, but it hides the word's roots. "Poem" comes from the Greek "poí?ma," meaning "a thing made," and a poet is "a maker of things."

So, if a poem is a thing made, what kind of thing is it? Poets sometimes compare poems to wild animals – untameable and unpredictable – or to machines – precise and human-made – depending on their view. But these comparisons don't hold up under scrutiny. The value in trying to define a poem through comparison is not in the comparison itself but in the discussion it sparks. Whether you see a poem as a machine or a wild animal, this process can change how you think about machines or wild animals. It helps the mind explore new ways of thinking and see ordinary things differently.

The idea of a poem as a mental object is not hard to grasp, especially if we think about how song lyrics can stick in our minds. The mix of words and melody has a strong effect, like schoolyard rhymes such as "Sticks and stones may break my bones, but words can never hurt me." But aren't words sometimes like sticks and stones?

Consider a poem on a newspaper or magazine page, staring at you: A poem can hit home like nothing else, even though, in terms of ink on paper, it does nothing more than the prose around it. What about all that empty space around the poem – space that could have been used for a longer article or ad? A poem is created through writing and rewriting, just like an article, story, or novel, yet it never really becomes what they usually are – a commodity. Publishing houses send out press releases and review copies of poetry collections, but few expect them to cover printing costs. A poem presents itself not as a market item, but as something for its own sake. Because of its special status – set apart in a magazine or book – a poem can still surprise us, even if only for a moment.

I bought my first metal detector soon after I got married. Back then, £70 was a lot of money and could have been used for something more practical for the house. However, my wife, Marion, was impressed when I found a gold ring worth £80 on my first try. Over the years, every brooch and coin I've found has brought me joy because it connects me to the past. But after the gold ring, it took 40 years to find something else that impressed Marion as much.

One dull February afternoon, I had some free time and a place in mind to search. It was raining, so I chose a closer spot known for old farming machinery. The first time my detector beeped, I found a piece of a metal wheel. Then it beeped again. I couldn't ignore it and started digging. Half a metre down, lying in the mud, I saw a rounded, golden object. I tried not to get too excited, thinking it might be brass. But as I cleared the dirt, it turned into a beautifully patterned loop. I stopped and stared, realizing it looked like the Great Torc from the British Museum, a famous piece from Iron Age Britain over 2,000 years ago. A torc is a twisted necklace of gold and silver, with gold rings at each end, just like the one I found.

I took it to my car and couldn't stop looking at it on the drive home. I washed it in my kitchen sink, probably the first clean it had in ages. I called Marion, saying, "I've got something for you." She came in, stopped, and asked, "What is it?" I explained it was a very old and rare piece of jewelry. We didn't try it on, fearing we might damage it. At bedtime, I hid it in our wardrobe, but anxiety kept me awake. Eventually, I hid it under a floorboard in my office.

The law requires such finds to be reported within 14 days. I wanted to enjoy the torc before giving it up, even taking it in a plastic bag to show a friend in the hospital. Finally, I took it to the council office. The registrar was talking to someone when I placed the torc on his desk. He turned, stopped mid-sentence, and stared. The torc was authenticated and sold to my local council. It's now in the British Museum in London. The £350,000 proceeds were split between the field's owner and me. But the torc is more than just a lucky find; it's something I've saved for the nation. People ask if I'll stop detecting now that I've found something so amazing. But those brooches and coins are still interesting. Like a fisherman who catches a big fish, I won't stop while there's a chance of finding something even bigger.

Sleeping is one of my favorite parts of traveling, but I don't often talk about it because I feel a bit guilty. When friends describe their carefully planned trips, filled with activities like visiting museums and hiking, I just smile and listen. What would they think if they knew my travel plans include time for afternoon naps during Caribbean rainstorms and lazy mornings in Italian sheets? Better sleep is a happy side effect of travel. When I visited Mexico's Yucatán coast in my early 20s, I was surprised by how much I slept—more than 12 hours most days. Even with noisy birds nearby, I could sleep deeply and dreamily, more than I thought possible. Without alarm clocks and responsibilities, sleep comes more easily. But I don't think just relaxing explains why travel sleep feels so different. I believe sleep is part of our travel experience, not just a break from it. When we travel, we encounter new sights, sounds, and smells. We absorb new cultures, music, and landscapes. During sleep, we process all this new information. That's why sleep feels more intense when traveling. Sleep also changes with each place. People worry about jet lag, but I think adjusting to local customs affects me more than time zones. In Trinidad, for example, people wake up early to avoid the heat, rest around 10 a.m., and become active again in the evening. Even though Trinidad is just one hour ahead of New York, it takes me days to adjust to this pattern. Once I do, I feel like I've truly arrived. I remember an afternoon in Santo Domingo, where I shared a big meal with new friends. After eating, everyone slowly stopped talking and moved to hammocks and sofas to rest. I realized why there were so many pillows around. I joined them and experienced the Latin American tradition of the siesta. I shared not just sleep, but a part of Dominican life. Travel sleep is memorable. Away from my usual routine, I enjoy the new smells, textures, and sounds that fill my dreams. If 'slow travel' means enjoying every moment instead of rushing, then what is slower than sleep? Maybe I should stop feeling embarrassed and tell my friends that travel sleep is an activity too.

The woman turned away from the mirror. "What do you think? And be honest." Mia picked up a medium-sized hat with a soft layer of gauze and a silk bow. "I still think this one suits you best," she said diplomatically. The woman wrinkled her nose and frowned, looking like a bulldog. "But it's so boring," she said. "Every other woman will wear a hat like that at my daughter’s wedding. This little beauty will make me stand out." She patted the red and black mini top hat on her head. "Yes," she decided, "this is the one I want." Mia knew she couldn't change her mind, so she smiled and agreed that the woman would indeed stand out at the wedding. She thought of her own daughter, Jen, whose thirtieth birthday was today. They were having a family gathering, and Mia was excited to see Jen, Dan, and Luke. She was also curious about Jen's friend, Tattie, whom they knew nothing about. When Jen called last week to ask if she could bring Tattie, Mia's husband Jeff had commented, "What sort of name is that?" Mia explained, "It's short for Tatiana. I think it’s nice." Jeff, who disliked anything pretentious, replied, "More like something very affected." He also didn't believe in being overly polite, unlike Mia. He would have told the woman in the shop that she was choosing the wrong hat and might have even joked that a dustbin lid would suit her better. "The trouble with you, Mia," he often said, "is that you’re too polite for your own good." An hour later, Mia closed her shop and entered Medlar House through the back door. Her commute was only forty seconds. Four years ago, when their youngest child, Luke, left home, Mia decided to convert the unused barn next to their house into a bright space for her business. Jeff was doubtful. "Do you really think there's a demand for hats?" he asked. Mia knew from friends that there was a demand for the perfect hat for special occasions. She was right. After Jen helped her create a website, Mia’s Hats became a success. Women came from miles around to her showroom in Little Pelham, where they could try on many hats in a relaxed setting. She encouraged customers to bring their outfits to ensure a perfect match. Recently, she expanded her business to include handbags and costume jewelry.

It's a long journey from London to Atlanta, and Lawrence Okoye is reflecting on his incredible sports career. He is confident, yet even he is surprised by how far he has come—from competing in the Olympic discus final to possibly joining a major American football team. Despite never having played American football before, Lawrence is likely to be selected by a top USA team. In Atlanta, he is still learning the details of his new position. The idea that a 21-year-old from London could be chosen for one of the biggest teams in American sports is remarkable. But Lawrence is used to defying expectations. He was offered a place at Oxford University to study law but delayed it to focus on discus, after previously playing rugby. Within 20 months, he became the world’s fourth-best discus thrower. Lawrence originally went to Atlanta for warm-weather discus training, aiming for the world championships. When asked about his sudden interest in a potential NFL career, he confirms, "American football was in the back of my mind, but I decided to try it when I got to the USA. I had thought about it in school, but it seemed crazy then." Soon after arriving in America, he learned about NFL trials in Atlanta. Even though he had never played, did he think he could be chosen? "Pretty much," he says. "I applied online." Was he nervous about competing with experienced players? "No," he says. "I don’t get nervous for many things." He is not very talkative, but his confidence is clear. His performance in tests and drills made him stand out as the most impressive player. "I was very pleased to hear that," he admits, showing a rare sign of pride. However, he is cautious. Without any basic experience, how can he make it into an NFL team? "Coaches say I have all the attributes needed. It’s about how hard I work," he replies. Is he relaxed while waiting to hear if he’s been selected? "I am. There’s no pressure on me. Many people say I’ll be selected, but I’m not too worried." This calmness might come from his disappointing Olympic final, where he finished last. He seems to have moved past this and is proud of qualifying for the final with an impressive last throw. "That was an amazing day," he says. "The final didn’t go as I wanted, but that’s part of sport. I can return to it." After the Olympics, some thought the experience had affected him. Lawrence doesn’t comment. The minimum NFL salary is over $400,000 a year, so the financial benefits are clear. Lawrence has switched from rugby to athletics and now to American football. With his talents, wouldn’t it be better to focus on one sport? "I understand why someone would say that," he responds. "I’m trying to achieve something I dreamed of as a schoolkid. If it doesn’t work out, I can go back to discus, the sport I love. Every decision I’ve made has been thought through."

We had been flying east all night, and I woke up to see it was already daylight. Looking out the window, I saw the empty landscape below. The dark shades of brown and green reassured me that, although it was mid-September, winter had not yet arrived in Siberia. There was no sign of human life, just an endless view of mountains, streams, and forests. I shook my head. My neighbor woke up and smiled at me sleepily. "Good morning, Robert," he said in a slow, Russian accent. Sergei was a salesman from Moscow traveling to remote areas to sell safety clothing to local mining industries. His English was almost as poor as my Russian, but with a dictionary, I explained that I was flying to the far-eastern Siberian city of Magadan with a one-way ticket because I planned to return to England by bicycle. "But, Robert," he said, "there is no road from Magadan; you cannot ride a bicycle." I explained that I believed there was a road, though not many people used it. "Alone?" he asked. "No, I will be riding with a friend named Al." "Just one friend?" "Yes, just one," I nodded. Sergei still looked unconvinced and said, "Holodna" (cold), pointing outside. I tried to reassure him with hand gestures that I had warm clothes, though I didn't mention that my trip was self-funded and I was on a tight budget. Most of my clothes and equipment were bought at discounted prices. I wasn't sure they would be adequate, especially my large postman’s over-trousers, which I bought for £10. It all started in a lecture hall in Scotland. The hall was full of students, some taking notes without energy. The lecturer droned on. I was thinking about a dilemma. Should I ask him or not? "Well, why not?" I tore a sheet from my pad and wrote, "Hi Al, Do you want to cycle across the Karakorum Highway between Pakistan and China this summer? Rob." In front of me sat Al, my old school friend. I tapped him on the shoulder and passed the note. He read it, scratched his head, wrote something, and passed it back. I unfolded it and held my breath. "OK," it said. Six years later, I was going to join Al in Siberia. I had been working as a geography teacher, and although I was still learning to manage my classes, the job was fulfilling. It was challenging, rarely boring, and offered long holidays for adventures. Twice since I started teaching, I had used these holidays to meet Al. He had caught the adventure bug after our bike ride through Pakistan and decided to do something more relaxing than teaching: cycling around the world. Since our first ride, Al had been setting greater challenges for himself. This round-the-world bike trip was his greatest so far. At times, he thought the ride or the road would break him. Although it sounded tough, I envied him. He was having an extraordinary adventure, finding he could handle each new challenge, even if it seemed impossible. He was proving wrong those who doubted him. He was doing something that scared him nearly every day, and it made him feel alive.

In the Red Bull Air Race, twelve pilots take turns racing through pylons that are 15 to 25 meters high. They make sharp turns, barrel rolls, and loops at speeds up to 370 km per hour. I was invited to experience what it's like to participate. An hour before the flight, I signed two forms. The first confirmed I was in good health, and the second required me to empty my pockets, as small objects can be dangerous during the flight. I learned I needed to stay oriented. "The horizon is your best friend," I was told, and the pilot would guide me on where to look. I was also asked to relax and enjoy the view when flying upside down.

Half an hour before the flight, I had a safety briefing. I was instructed not to touch anything. As we taxied down the runway, my legs were up, trying not to touch the steering pedals, and my hands avoided the switches. My mind was made up: I would not relax and enjoy the flight. This is the challenge of high-speed acrobatic flying. To avoid passing out, you must stay calm and focused, tensing and relaxing at the right times. Panicking is not an option. This was not comforting as we accelerated down the runway.

Dario, the pilot, and I reached the end of the runway in the Zivko Edge 540, one of the fastest acrobatic planes. The plane took off, and we immediately banked sharply to the right. It was a sudden move, and I felt the air squeeze out of my lungs. I looked at the horizon, tensed up, and took short breaths as I sank into the seat. For a moment, I weighed 6.2 times my normal weight. Then we leveled out. We turned sharply left and dived, leaving my stomach at 2,000 meters and my lungs pressed against the roof of the plane. Seconds later, we were 10 meters off the ground, heading for the small gap between two pylons. They passed at 400 km per hour, but my excitement was cut short by a sharp right turn. We hadn't even started the acrobatics yet.

For two minutes, I was allowed to fly the plane. My hand shook so much that the plane shook too—it’s that responsive. Then Dario said something, and I asked him to repeat it. Instead of replying, he did a barrel roll, a full 360-degree turn. "Are you okay?" he asked. "Yup," I replied. "Have you had enough?" "No," I lied. Then he did a loop, flying the plane in a full circle. I know many people find this exciting, like those who enjoy rollercoasters. However, I thought it was too much. At the top of the loop, flying upside down, I heard a small voice saying, "Relax, relax, look up." I looked up and saw fields. The flight lasted 10 minutes. It was "soft" compared to what pilots endure in races. To prove the point, Dario ate sandwiches as soon as we landed. I didn’t eat for hours, and that night, I dreamed of doing loops repeatedly.

Doug Allan films wild animals in cold places. If you've ever been amazed by footage of polar bears in a nature documentary, it was probably filmed by him. His ideal temperature, he says, is -18°C. Allan trained as a marine biologist and commercial diver. Diving was his first passion, where he learned about surviving in cold places. His big break came when a TV crew arrived in Antarctica, where Allan was working, to film a wildlife documentary. "I ended up taking the crew to different places, and after 48 hours I realized that being a wildlife cameraman ticked all the boxes: travel, adventure, underwater." He is now a top cameraman and has worked on many major TV wildlife series. "I came along at a good time. When I started, hardly anyone had been to the Antarctic. You had coral people, elephant people, chimpanzee people. I just became the cold man. It was like all these amazing sequences were just waiting to be captured on film." The camera and communications technology was very basic when he started 35 years ago. "It is certainly easier to film today. If you shot something then, you had to remember it. Today, with digital technology, you can shoot a lot and look at it immediately. You used to have to think about what shots you needed next, and what you had missed. You shot less. Film was very expensive. Today you can have too much material." "My value is field experience in cold conditions. I have a feel for it. I have spent so much time on sea ice it now feels like crossing the street. I do get cold toes but the poles are healthy places. There are no leeches, no diseases or mosquitoes." Wildlife filming, Allan says, is full of great successes, but also failures and embarrassments. Once, he was in the Orkneys to film kittiwakes. Unfortunately, he could not identify which birds they were. When Allan recently got permission to film sequences for a major TV series in Kong Karls Land, a group of islands in the Arctic Ocean, he did not expect an easy assignment. It is a world of polar bears and is strictly off-limits to all but the most fearless or foolish. Usually -32°C in April, the wind is vicious and hauling cameras in the deep snow is a nightmare. After walking five or more hours a day and watching polar bear dens in the snow slopes for 23 days, however, Allan had seen just one mother bear and her cub. By day 24, though, he says, he was living in bear world, at bear speed, with bear senses. "We find a new hole and wait. We shuffle, hop, bend, stretch and run to stay warm.
